div.head: Chapter V
History of the Songai kings of the shî dynasty and especially of shî Ali.
div.p: It is now time for us to return to our subject, which is the biography of the askia. We have dwelt on all these characters1, thus following a path which it was not in our designs to follow; there was indeed no result to be obtained from it, since it is almost certainly the case that the major part of the preceding accounts is fictitious. We ask God the Most High for his forgiveness. Lord, be praised and glorified! I declare that there is no other god but you, I ask your forgiveness and return to you.

After the shî Bâro-Dal-Yombo2 reigned the shî Mâdogo3, then the shî Mohammed-Koûkiya, then the shî Mohammed-Fâri, then the shî Balma, then the shî Souleïmân-Dâma5, who, according to some versions, was called Dândi. The latter was the ancestor of the inhabitants of the city of Arham.6
That is, Kankan-Moûssa, the kings of the Kaniâga and the kayamaga. شی. This is the dynastic title that the Tarikh es-Soudân spells sonni and of which the variants soun, sin, tyin, etc., are found. The dynasty of the shî or sonni, descended from that of the diâ or zâ which had preceded it, reigned in Gâo from 1335 to 1493. It seems, from the testimony of Leo the African, that these two dynasties were of Berber origin; Marmol and Barth shared this opinion.
This prince must have reigned in Gâo in the early fifteenth century.
Or Mâdao.
The names of five of the six kings mentioned here are found in the Tarikh es-Soudân in the forms Bokar-Dalla-Boyombo, Mohammed-Dâ'o, Mohammed-Koûkiya, Mohammed-Fâr and Souleïmân-Dâm; the list of the Tarikh es-Sudân does not contain a prince by the name of Balma, but, on the other hand, it interposes Mâr-Kiraï between Bokar-Dalla-Boyombo and Mohammed-Dâ'o and four kings (Karbifo, Mâr-Faï-Kolli-Djimo, Mâr-Arkona and Mâr-Arandan) between Mohammed-Fâr and Souleïmân-Dâm.
Location about 30 kilometers east of Goundam, in the Kissou.
It was he who defeated the people of the province of Mîma1, sacked their territory () and annihilated their power. Previously this province formed a great kingdom, of formidable power, which had broken away from the empire of Malli. There were in the Mîma twelve great chiefs, of whom the principal was the Mîma-kono2. Among the other princes of the Mîma was the Toukifiri-sôma3; before him the king of the Mâssina had to stand and cover himself with dust as he swore loyalty to him and took off his boubou4 and then draped himself in it; traces of his capital, ruined today, can still be seen. The title of this prince has continued to the present day, but he who now bears it has fallen away and is obliged to go on foot, having no mount; his authority has disappeared, but his title has remained (praise be to the eternal Sovereign!). The king of Mâssina goes to visit this personage still, claiming that it brings him good luck; he consults him and asks him to pray for him; he dismounts his mount to greet him and goes to find him in the place where his now ruined capital once stood.

The successor of Silmân-Dâma was the tyrant, the debauchee, the accursed, the oppressor, the shî Ali5, the last king of this
Name of the region on the left bank of the Niger between the Mâssina and the great lakes.
ميم قن. We do not know the etymology of this title; if it belongs to the Mandingo language, it could mean "the center of the Mina."
تكفر سذم. Same remark as for the previous title. The Toukifiri-sôma must have been the representative of the native population of the Mîma, and this was probably the reason for the honors paid to him by the king of the Mâssina. The msc. C spells: Noukifiri.
This is the word قميس (shirt) which we translate as "boubou," a term commonly used today to refer to the loose garment in use in Sudan that is in question here.
This king, known as the shî or sonni Ali or Ali-Ber (i.e., in Songai "Ali the-Great") ruled from about 1465 to 1492.
dynasty, whose entourage imitated his ignoble conduct. He was always victorious and sacked all the countries on which he had set his sights. None of his armies was ever routed: always victorious, never defeated. He left no region, no town, no village, from the land of Kanta1 to Sibiridougou, without attacking it at the head of his cavalry, warring against the inhabitants and ravaging their territory.

The meaning of this word shî is thus given, according to a text which I have seen, written in the hand of Mahmûd,2 one of our imâms: The meaning of shî, he says, is koï-benendi,3 i.e., the khalif of the sultan, his deputy, his substitute.

The shî Ali was a tyrannical king, so hard-hearted that he sometimes had a child thrown into a mortar and forced the mother to pound it, the latter having to pound her child while it was still alive; the flesh was then fed to the horses. He was debauched and impious, so much so that one of the sheikhs of his time, inhabiting Môri-Koïra, was asked whether this prince was a Muslim or an infidel, his actions being those of an infidel although he pronounced the double profession of Muslim faith and spoke as one well versed in the things of religion.

See, from his deeds, what his impiety was: he had jurisconsults put to death! And how many villages he destroyed, causing their inhabitants to perish in the flames! He inflicted
Name of an ancient kingdom whose location corresponded to the present-day province of Kebbi, located east of Dendi. The country stretching from the Kanta to the Sibiridougou corresponds to the valley of the Niger from northern Dahomey to the vicinity of Segou.
We do not know which character is being referred to here.
كى بنند. This expression can indeed mean replace the chief or supplement the chief in the Songai language, but this indication does not tell us anything about the origin or etymology of the word shî.
all sorts of tortures on people: sometimes he used fire to make them perish, sometimes () he had a living being walled up to let him die like that, and finally he had the belly of a living woman cut open to remove the foetus! In sum, his acts of cruelty and his disastrous administrative procedures were so numerous that this volume would not be sufficient to enumerate them.

He was invested with the kingship of Songai in the year 69 of the ninth century [September 3, 1464 - August 23, 1465] and held power for twenty-seven years, four months and fifteen days, that is, until the year 897 [November 4, 1491 - October 22, 1492], according to what I have extracted from the work entitled Dorer el-hisân fî akhbâr ba'd moloûk es-Soûdân, a work whose author is Bâba Goûro ben El-Hâdj Mohammed ben El-Hâdj El-Amîn Gânoû1.

He had no enemies whom he hated as keenly as the Fulani and could not see a Fulani without killing him no matter who he was, scholar or ignorant, man or woman2, He did not accept any Fulani scholar either in the political administration or in the judiciary. He decimated the Sangaré tribe3 and left only a tiny fraction of it remaining, which was able to
This work, whose title means roughly the beautiful pearls of the history of a part of the kings of Sudan (درر الحسان في اخبار بعض ملوك السودان), is unknown to us; it would no doubt be interesting to find a copy. Mohammed ben El-Amin Gânoû (or Kâno), father of the author of this work, is cited by the Tarikh es-Soudân as having miraculously escaped the massacre to which the jurisconsults of Timbuktu fell victim on October 20, 1593 (Cf. Tarikh es-Soudan, translation, pp. 258-261). Mahmûd Kâti had been dead for about a month at that time. From other excerpts from the same work which will be found quoted below, it appears that it was composed no earlier than the middle of the seventeenth century.
لا فتله لا عالم ولا جاهل لا رجال ولا نساء: oddly constructed sentence whose exact translation remains uncertain.
شنقر. Name of a Fulani tribe – or clan - which is called also Bari and to which in Mâssina is often given the name Sissê.
gather in the shade of a single tree that was enough to shelter it all.
He would seize Muslims of free condition and give them away to other Muslims, claiming to be making an act of generosity by doing so.

The people of his time and his soldiers had given him the nickname of Dâli as an honorary title and whenever he called out to someone, they would reply, Dâli ! One of our friends, Mohammed Wangara ben Abdallah ben Sandioûka El-Foulâni1 (God have mercy on him!) told me that he had heard it said by Aboulabbâs Sîdi Ahmed ben Anda-ag-Mohammed (God have mercy on him! ): It is not lawful to give such a nickname to anyone, for this word means the most high2 and must be reserved for the Master of all power, who is God the most high. The same is true of Doûlinta those who say Doûrinta commit a fault - an expression which means the slave of the Master3: now, by "Master" who used this expression meant the chî4 (the curse of God () be upon him!). As for this term Dâli, it is used today only when addressing the Koûma-koï5 and the Dienné-koï. It is appropriate that scrupulous people and tâlebs pay attention to the above remark.
div.note: That is, Muhammad the Wangara son of Abdallah son of Sandioûka. سنجوك the Fulani.
It is likely in the Songai language that dâli has this meaning.
In today's Songai language "the slave of the master" can expressed doû-ditam.

The author probably means that the slaves or servants of the shî were given the appellation of slaves of the Master, which amounted to conferring on the shî a title that belongs only to God, such as that of Most High.
كومكى. This term, whose second part (koï) means chief in Songai, may apply to the chief of Koûma or Goûma, a town southeast of Saraſéré, or to the chief of some other village of similar name.
div.p: This shî spent his entire reign in warlike expeditions: he had royal residences at Koûkiya1, at Gâo and at Kabara2; the latter was called Tila; he had yet another at Warain the province of Dirma5: this one was in the vicinity of the city of Ankaba6 and faced the city of Diendiao7; but he did not stay in any of them. The shî who had preceded him resided in Koûkiya, but the shî Ali, this scoundrel, was constantly on expeditions.

At the beginning of his reign, he had gone to the city of Dîreï8. Then, having had news of the king of the Môssi named Komdâo9, he left Dîreï to put himself in a position to meet him,
كوكيا. Koûkiya or Gounguia was the ancient capital of Songai; after the transfer of the capital to Gâo (beginning of the tenth century CE), Koûkiya still often served as the residence of kings. This city must have been near present-day Bentia, about 150 kilometers downstream from Gâo on the Niger,.
Port of Timbuktu on the Niger.
Tila is a locality in the suburbs of Kabara, east of that city.
ورع. Wara or Aouré is on the right bank of the Niger (or Issa-Ber) about twenty kilometers north of Lake Débo.
Dirma is, strictly speaking, the province between the Issa-Ber and the Bara-Issa, north of Lake Débo; the same name is sometimes given, by extension, to the entire Niger region between Dienné and Timbuktu.
لنكب. This is probably the village of Diankabé, located on the Bara-Issa, east of Wara.
جنجو. Village on the left bank of the Niger (Issa-Ber), opposite Wara.
دير in A and B, ديرى in C: this is most likely Dîreï or Dîré, near to, and north of, El-Waledji, east of Lake Fati; it could also, an least in A and B, read Déra, east of Lake Débo and a little upstream of the southern tip of Lake Korienza.
This is probably Nâsséré I or Nâssodoba, who ruled over the Môssi (موشى) of Yâtenga from 1475 to about 1500 and who pillaged Walata in 1480; it was on his return from Walata, in 1483, that he was attacked by the shî Ali, according to the Tarikh es-Soudân, and it was against this prince, whom this work calls Nâsséré نعسر, that the askia Muhammad made an expedition in 1498. The word kom seems to be in Mossi a kind of title; Komdâo (كمداع) was perhaps a surname of the emperor Nasseri. According to our author, the battle of Kobi would have taken place at the beginning of Ali's reign and before the march of the Môssi on Walata, as we shall see later.
reached him at Kobi1, routed his troops, and pursued him to the Bambara2; Komdâo managed to save himself personally, return to his country, and return to his capital, which was called Argouma2.

The shî Ali then retraced his steps, accompanied by the Timbuktu-koï Mohammed Naddi4, by the askia Mohammed and the latter's brother, the Kourmina-fâri Amar. The chief of Timbuktu Mohammed Naddi, the faren Afoumba6, Aboubakar7 and the faren Ousmân had taken part in this expedition.

When the month of Ramadan began, the shî Ali
كب. Presumably at the village of Kobi, located south of Lake Débo, unless it was at Kobé, between Korienza and Saraſéré, or at Kebbi, south of Lake Korienza.
That is, as far as the country of the Bambara, which, speaking from the north, begins about the height of Dienné.
بنبر. Probably a locality in Yâtenga; local traditions say that at the time in question the ruler's usual residence was at Sissamba, near and southwest of Wahigouya.
This personage, who belonged to a Zenâga family originally from Chinguetti (Adrar Mauritanien), was chief or mayor of Timbuktu (in Songai Timbuktu-koï) at the time when the rule of the emperor of Malli ceased to be exercised over that city (1433); He remained in office during the reign of the Tuareg sultan Akil, who was suzerain of Timbuktu from 1433 to 1467. The Tarikh es-Soudân has Muhammad Naddi die between the advent of shî Ali (1464-1465) and his entry to Timbuktu (29 or 30 January 1468): he could therefore not have accompanied this prince on his return from the battle of Kobi, if one were to adopt the date of 1483 given to this battle by the above-mentioned work.
This is the character who was later to become king of Songai and who was then one of the officers of the shî Ali. About the use of the title of askia in the time of the shî, see what the author says a little further on.
This character will be discussed further below; the title given to him and his colleague Usman means "chief" or "governor" in the Mandinka language and is spelled برن or فارن
This Aboubakar was either the father of the askia Muhammad or one of the sons of the shî Ali.
found himself in the land of the Bambara; he made the prayer of the Feast [of the breaking of the fast] in Koutté1, then returned to Koûnâ.2 From Koûnâ, he made an expedition against Bisma3, whom he killed. Then he went to Tamsa4, where he was in the time of Ramadan, and it is in Tamsa that he made the prayer of the Feast5. From there, he went in pursuit of the Beïdân6, until the day when, having arrived at Dâ7 he killed the môddibo Wara8. Then he went to Fakiri9 and left Fakiri to return to Tamsa, where he was at the time of Ramadan; it was in Tamsa that he performed the prayer of the Festival. He seized the person of El-Mokhtâr10 in the city of Kikéré11 and fought the inhabitants of Tondi 12. Then he returned in the direction of
كتتع. This locality must have been on the right bank of the Bani, about opposite Dienné.
كونع. This is probably Koûnâ, chief town of Koûnâri on the right bank of the Bani upstream from Mopti.
No doubt a chief of the Tombo or Habé mountainous region .
تمسع. Probably a locality in the Bandiagara region,
That is, a year had passed since the time when the shî had pursued the Bambara up to the emperor of Yâtenga.
بيدان. This name designates a fraction of a Fulani tribe, as we shall see later.
داع. Probably Dâ or Dê, a village that lies between Bandiagara and Douentza.
This is probably a Fulani marabout. For the explanation of the word môdibbo (مودب), see note 1, page 26. This character is called Ouâna in the mscr. C.
فكر. We do not know how to vocalize this word, which we have not been able to identify, unless it refers to Fakara, a province on the left bank of the lower Niger, east of Niamey, which would be unlikely. It is not clear from the context who this character was. ككر. . Probably Kikéré or Kikéra north-northeast of Douentza.
تند. Tondi is a Songai word meaning stone, rock, rocky mountain; the Hombori cliff, which lies east of Kikéré, is so called.
Soûra-Ban-tambà1. Then, resuming his journey, he returned to Gâo, whose name offers the dialectal variants of Gâo and Gaogao , he was in that city at the time of Ramadan and it was there that he performed the Festival prayer.

Then shî Ali sent () the askia Baghna to make an expedition against Tosko,2 - Note the use of this term askia from the time of the shî dynasty, which is contrary to the general opinion that the askia Mohammed was the first to bear this title and to attach it to his name and thus explaining the origin of this denomination as a dynastic nickname, as we shall shortly discuss in giving the biography of the askia Mohammed; this is a very singular fact. - Tosko routed the troops of the askia Baghna.

The army of shî Ali was then at the village of Mansoura4. The prince was in Mansoura at the beginning of the month of Ramadan; he made the prayer of the Feast in Koûkiya, then he turned back to return to Gâo. He then left at the head of his troops on the side of Azaouat3, and it was at the time of this
سور بنتنبع. The Tarikh es-Sudan speaks of a country of this name as located "in the Malli" and containing Arabs to whom the askia Dâoud waged war in 1570, with the help of Tuareg contingents (cf. Tarikh es-Soudân, translation, pp. 177-178). The expression means in Songai "desert (bantambâ) of the Moors (Soûra)" and seems to apply generally to the part of the Sahara north and northwest of Timbuktu; it is used quite frequently, on the side of Timbuktu, to refer simply to the north.
تسك. The text does not indicate whether this is an individual, a locality, or a tribe. The Tarikh es-Sudan cites two cases of Tosko, one of which is said to have taken place in 1479 and the other in 1488.
According to the Tarikh es-Soudân, Muhammad is said to have taken the title of askia, in a way out of irony, because the daughters of the shî Ali, on learning that the conqueror of their brother Bâro had become master of the kingdom, had cried out askia, an expression which, in the language of the country, meant he is not; a si kyi a or a si tyi a indeed means in Songai he is not or he will not.
Or Mansour, a small village located in the suburbs of Gâo.
ازوت. This is probably the Azaouat or Azaouad, a Saharan region which borders Niger in its northern part and where Arabs and Tuareg live.
expedition that the askia Baghna died; the shî Ali then set out for Tasgo1. He was in the town of Nâsséré2, in the country of the Môssi, when Ramadan began, and there he performed the Festival prayer.

After that, he went by the river to Lôlo,3 and raised a very large army and put it all under the command of the Dendi-fâri4 Afoumba, whom he sent on an expedition; in this army was the hîkoï5 Boukar. – Note also the use, from this time, of this term hîkoï, which is also contrary to the statement of the Songai people, who say that it was created only in the time of the askia Muhammad and who explain the use of the title hîkoï in this way; we will discuss this in the course of the biography of the askia Muhammad. - In this army was also the askia Mohammed, who then bore the title of Tondi-farma6: there was also his brother Amar-Komdiâgo,7
تسك. We do not know if this is the name of a locality or a province.
نعسر. That is, in the city where Násséré, emperor of Yâtenga, resided. (see note 9, page 85).
لول. mscr. C vocalizes Laolo. Name of a locality on the Niger downstream from the Dendi.
That is, of the chief of the Dendi; the Dendi was the southernmost province of Songai: this country straddles the lower Niger, between Niamey and the Boussa rapids. The title of Dendi-fâri was given to one of the principal dignitaries of the court..
. هيكى. This word means in Songai chief of the dugouts, chief of the flotilla; it was the title of one of the principal dignitaries of the Songai kingdom,
i.e., chief or governor of the mountain (see note 12, p. 87, on the word Tondi, and note 6, page 71, on the terms farma, fâri, faren, etc.).
عمر كمزاغ. This is the same character referred to elsewhere as Kourmina-fari Amar or kanfâri Amar.
who was then Kotalo-farma1, as well as the faren Usmân. This expedition was sent to help Mohammed-Koïrao to carry out reprisals against the kankoï".

As for Chî Ali, he returned to Gâo, but he did not stay there and marched on Barkona4, a city where the royal residence of the Môssi-koï was then located5. He destroyed this city and took its inhabitants prisoner, whom he then made perish in a barbaric way. He then led an expedition against the people of Moli6, but they fled and he did not succeed in reaching them. He then returned and equipped a considerable army, at the head of which he placed as general the hikoi Yâté, with orders to put to death the tenga-niama7; once the latter was killed, this army returned to the shî, and the latter went with it towards Kikéré, where he seized the person of the moundio Kountis.

Then he equipped () another army and sent with it the Dendi-fâri Afoumba with the mission to kill the Beïdân
كتل فرم. That is, chief or governor of Kotalo; we have not been able to identify the province or locality designated by this name.
محمد كيرو. This character was one of the dignitaries of the kingdom; he is referred to in the rest of the narrative.
The word translated here as reprisal refers in a technical way to the compensation due in matters of injury; that due in cases of murder has another name. As for the word kankoi, of which we are not sure (the text bears كنكى, it obviously designates the holder of a dignity which may have had some relationship with that of kanfâri instituted later by the askia Mohammed, koï and fâri being more or less synonymous.
Locality of Yâtenga. The mscr. C spells Barkoba.
That is, the king of the Môssi; here, as in the preceding passages, it is, not the ruler of the country which we call more particularly the Mossi, or country of Wagadougou, but the ruler of Yâtenga.
This is probably a Môssi village or tribe.
تنك نيعمع. This expression probably refers to a high dignitary of the Yâtenga empire; the word tenga means land, soil, country in Môssi.
For the meaning of moundio, see note 2, page 60.
Manuscripts A and B each carry a note in the margin indicating that the Beïdân were a portion of the Fulani tribe of Senfatîri (B) or Senfentir (A). The Tarikh-es-Soudân also speaks of a Fulani tribe of that name, against which the shî Ali is said to have made an expedition; one of the Fulani women captured in the course of this raid was given in marriage to the imâm of Timbuktu, and from this marriage the maternal grandmother of the father of Sa'di, the author of the Tarikh-es-Soudân, was born.
who were in the city of Noûma1. Then the faren Afoumba went to the Dendi, sent there the shî Ali to settle an affair, while the moundio Wanki brought the army back to the shî Ali.

This one had set out on a march. The month of Ramadan found him in Dâ2, where he made the prayer of the Feast and from where, resuming his march, he went to Dienné. The moundio Wanki, accompanied by the army, had preceded him there, and it was at Dienné that he met the shî. The latter was in Dienné at the time of Ramadan and it was there that he performed the Festival prayer. He fought the people of Dienné and twice the people of Malli. Then, resuming his journey, he carried the Fulani to Gaogao3; Ramadan found him at Diâkou and he performed the Festival prayer at Kanao. In the following Ramadan, he was in Kadyibi, where he performed the prayer of the Festival. The following Ramadan found him in Diarka and he performed the festival prayer in Manti.4 From there he returned to the River. He found himself at the time of Ramadan at Moli, performed the prayer of the Feast at Yatolo5 and, continuing his journey, he returned to Gâo, where he arrived at the time of Ramadan and performed the prayer of the Feast.
div.note: One of the manuscripts seems to bear Koûma or Goûmu, which may be the true name of this locality; Gouma, southeast of Saraféré, is indeed in a region where Fulani are numerous.
داغ in B and داع in C. This is probably the nearby Bandiagara locality discussed earlier.
Presumably from the Fulani he had taken prisoner during his last expeditions.
We were unable to identify the five localities whose names precede; these names are spelled ظكوا or جلكو, كنو, كذب, جرك, منت.
يعتل. We do not know which locality is referred to here.
div.p: He then left Gâo on the 2nd of the month of Shaul to go to Tondi, fought the inhabitants of Tondi and camped at Do1, where he stayed for a month.

Then, hearing that the Môssi-koï was heading for Birou2 after having left the people of his house in Dîreï 3 he set out to pursue the Môssi-koï. When he arrived at Sila4, he killed the chief of Sila () , then continued his way to Kanto5, where he found himself in the month of Ramadan, and made the prayer of the Feast in Sâma6. On arriving in his turn at Sâma , the Môssi-koï learned that the shî had taken his family and taken away his wealth; then the Môssi-koï followed the footsteps of the shî and joined him, but, on seeing his army, he was seized with fear and, fleeing, he returned to his steps, retracing his route in the opposite direction. I have transcribed all this from the book of my grandfather the alfa Mahmoûd ben El-Hâdj El-Motawakkel7, a book written according to his indications by one of his pupils.
د
or دو. Perhaps this is the lake of Do, located south-southeast of Timbuktu, near Saraféré.
بير. This is the Sudanese name for the city of Walata.
This is a marginal note in the Arabic text that indicates that these are the people of the house of the Môssi-koï. Another note seems to say that Dîrei was a village belonging to this ruler; it is likely, however, that it is the village of the same name mentioned earlier (see page 85, note 8).
. There are several localities of this name in the valley of the Niger, notably Sila or Sela west-southwest of Dienné.
The mscr. A spells this word once كنتع and a second time كنتغ; the mscr. B gives كتتغ and the mscr. c كنتع. We do not know the location that it describes.
سام. One can read Sâma, Sâmé, Sâmi or Sâmo. Perhaps this is one of the villages named Sâma located near the Niger in the Ségou-Sansanding region; perhaps it is also the province of Sâma mentioned by Bekri as bordering Walata.
This sentence, obviously written by the grandson of Mahmûd Kâti, tells us that the above was simply copied from his grandfather's work.
-- The shî Ali having then left Dîrei, the two adversaries met at Kobi1.

It was in the year 873 that the city of Timbuktu was sacked by shî Ali, who entered it on the fourth day of the month of redjeb (18 January 1469). It was also in this same year that the very learned jurisconsult, the sheikh-el-islâm, the reviver of religion, the câdi Abouttsenâ Mahmoûd ben Omar ben Mohammed Aqît left Bîrou and returned to Timbuktu (God have mercy on him!).

Know that the shî, the askia Mohammed and the môri Haougâro, ancestor of the people of Môri-Koïra and the jurisconsults
If we count the number of times that the month of Ramadan recurred from the advent of the shî Ali until the time of his presence in Sâma, we find that thirteen to fourteen lunar years elapsed between these two periods; the coming of the prince having taken place in the year 869 of the hegira, it is therefore appropriate to place his presence in Sâma in the year 882-883, i.e. from 1477 to 1479 of our era. This is quite consistent with the indications of the Tarikh es-Soudân, which places the arrival of the Môssi emperor at Sâma in 1477 and at Bîrou (Walata) in 1480, and then places the battle of Kobi in 1483. There are ambiguities and contradictions in the above account, which may be due to the fact that one part of the account was written by the grandson while the other was borrowed from the work of his grandfather. Thus, he relates the affair of Kobi twice, seeming to place it first at the beginning of the reign of shî Ali and before the expedition of the Môssi to Walata, only to place it some fifteen years later; it is possible that, with regard to the stay that the shî made in Dîreï at the beginning of his reign, the author had anticipated the events by telling that it was from this locality that the prince was later to leave to go to Kobi to meetthe emperor of the Môssi. As for the present paragraph, it should probably be interpreted as follows: the Môssi marched on Walata, having left the baggage and family of their chief in Dîreï; the shî Ali, who was in the Niger buckle, set out on their tracks, arrived in the Bambara countries after their passage, put to death the chief of Sila to punish him for not having stopped them, then, having given up reaching them, went to Dîreï and seized the luggage and the household of their chief; the latter, during that time, had attacked and plundered Walata and returned to his country; on arriving near the Niger, he learned that the shî had seized his goods and his family, marched to meet him, was taken by fear when he saw his numerous army and resumed his march towards the south-east without pushing on to Dîreï; it is then that the shî, taking advantage of the disarray of his adversary, set out in pursuit and reached him at Kobi. The whole of these events occupied a period of six to seven years.
This character was then only five years old (cf. Tarikh es-Sudân, translation, p. 106). Ahmed-Bâba has given a biography of him.
of this locality, all have a common origin1, as well as all the people who bear the surname of Moï, such as the Moï-Dâ, the Moï-Nanko, the Moï-Haoua, the Moï-Kâ, the Moï-Firi, the Moï-Tâsso, the Moï-Goï, the Moï-Yôro and the Moï-Diâ; the name of the city where they come from was Yara2; all those who are in this region are originating from the west of the Wâkoré and the Wangara. However, I interviewed all the people I saw from the Kaniâga, the Bitou, the Malli, the Diâfounou, etc., asking them if they had in their country a tribe called Moï-Kâ or Moï-Nanko,5 and all of them answered me, We have never seen nor heard of anything like it.
This scoundrel, - I mean shî Ali, - was a prince who was obeyed, and his subjects feared him because of his cruelty.

While he was busy laying siege to Dienné, he sent a messenger to Timbuktu because he had heard that the inhabitants of Timbuktu were fleeing (), those from Bîrou returning to Bîrou, others going to Foutouti and Tichit, each seeking refuge in
This seems to contradict the opinion attributing to the shî a Berber origin.
Or Niara (نير
). A marginal note adds: Yara has long been destroyed. It may be that this city was one of those mentioned by Bekri and Edrissi as Yaressi and Gadiara, which must have been near the right bank of the Senegal in the Guidimakha.
That is, presumably, all the people with the nickname Moï who are in our region of Timbuktu. We don't know what this Moï surname (مى) is, and which tribes or families would have names beginning with Moï.
That is, from the western part of the countries inhabited by the peoples of the Mande family (Soninké and Mandingo).
The mscr. B here contains a word that can be read Moï-Natko (مينكت); it is probably the same word as previously spelled Moï-Nanko (مينكت). The mscr. C gives, in both passages, the reading Moï-Nika.
For the account of the siege of Dienne by Ali, cf. Tarikh es-Sudân, translation, pp. 26 ff.
his native land. He directed his messenger, at whatever hour he arrived at Timbuktu, to have it announced aloud that the king, the shî, had said that none of those who who had remained faithful to him should spend that night anywhere else than at Haoukiyi behind the River and that anyone who contravened this prescription would have his throat cut.1 The messenger arrived around noon; he beat the drum he had brought and the crowd gathered around him: The king, he said, commands you all to go to Haoukiyi. Then, drawing a sword that he held in his sleeve, he added: This is the king's sword, and the king has told me to use it to to cut the throat of anyone who stays in the city tonight. This is the account given by the narrator according to his master Mohammed-Bâba ben Yoûssof2.

In the blink of an eye, all the inhabitants left the city. Some did not even take supper with them that night, others did not take blankets to sleep on; some left on foot although they had horses in their houses, but they left them there for fear that the time to saddle them would delay them. Most of the weak people and the old men spent the night in Ariboro3, others in Dienta4; the rest crossed the river with the intention of spending the night on the other bank and several succeeded. The hour of sunset had not yet arrived when Timbuktu was already completely evacuated. Many of its inhabitants had left without closing
No doubt Haoukiyi (هوكى) was the name of a locality or region on the right bank of the Niger opposite Timbuktu.
Cousin of Mahmûd Kâti's grandson, as discussed below.
Which they call in our time Hariboro says a marginal note of mscr. B; ari or hari means "cau" in Songai and Hariboro is the name of a pond near Kabara,
جنتع. Dienta is an island in the Niger, south of and near Timbuktu.
the doors of their houses and, alone, had remained in the city the sick who had found no one to carry them and the blind who had had no one to lead them.

This will be enough to make you judge of the wickedness of the shî Ali. The worst of men is the one who is the one () feared only because of his wickedness. As for me, I hardly believe that such a thing was possible and I do not think that El-Haddjâdj ben Yoûssof1, in spite of his ardour to shed blood and his cruelty towards all, ever did anything similar to what was then done in Timbuktu nor that he saw his orders so punctually executed.

When the shî Ali had set out for the purpose of attacking Dienné, he had arrived at a village in the region named Chîtaï. The kouran2, having learned then that he was going against the Dienné-koï, cried out, It would be a disgrace to me if I did not repel a king who comes from his country to fight my master and who passes through our territory. Consequently, he took up arms and, having gathered a large army, he went to meet the shî, whom he surprised during the night. The shî responded to his attack and a fight with arrows began, which lasted until sunrise. The kouran was defeated and routed and the remnants of his army fled to Hâdjar3.

When the shî then arrived at Koûnâ 4, the tounkoï 5 acted
Muslim general, very famous for his cruelty, who lived in the second half of the seventh century of our era.
See note 2, page 64.
That is, in the land of stones; this is the name given by the Arabs to the region of the cliffs of Bandiagara and Hombori.
كونا. Locality on the right bank of the Bani, west-southwest of Bandiagara and north-northeast of Dienné. تنكى. This is likely to be one of the military officers of the chief of Dienné.
toward him as the kouran had done and was also routed. The soria1 also wanted to fight him and went against him, but the shî fell upon him at the head of an innumerable army and inflicted on him the same fate as on the two previous chiefs. Then the shî continued his march through the night, while the Dienné-koï, in spite of all this, slept peacefully on his royal bed, without being otherwise concerned.

Then, however, the Dienné-koï, at the head of a crowd of fighters whose number could not be estimated, went out in front of the enemy. The struggle began, and the fighting went on daily for six months. The Dienné-koï, who, according to the most accredited opinion, was then Komboro2, then returned to the city and, during the night, he had a tata3 built for himself; the very next morning, the river overflowed, surrounded the city with its waters and interposed itself between the two adversaries. The shî then blocked the city with the aid of four hundred dugouts, in order to prevent anyone from leaving or entering it. He did not give the inhabitants any truce until he had defeated and subdued them. Then, having crossed the walls of the place, he settled in the middle of the residence of the Dienné-koï with the intention of remaining there, but he was driven from it by vipers, serpents and scorpions, which alone compelled him to go away. He then went to live in a house situated south of the residence of the Dienné-koï and east of the great mosque and took possession of this house, where he left his people and baggage when he returned
سريح. This title was probably carried by a third-rate officer, subordinate to the kouran and the tounkoi.
Or Gomboro; several chiefs of Dienné bore this name.
Literally he had his wall built; this refers to an enclosure with which the chiefs of the Sudan were accustomed to surround the buildings of their residences, and not to the city walls themselves; we have made use of the word tata, commonly used in the Sudan in this sense.
in his country1. This house then belonged to the askia Mohammed; I saw with my own eyes the sections of the walls that still remained after its destruction2 ().

The ferocity of shî Ali towards the Muslims and his cruelty in all circumstances, whether it was a question of worldly things or those of religion, had become such that the courts were overflowing with sadness and concern. People despaired of ever achieving deliverance, for his reign had lasted so long that they had lost all hope of the day when these evils would cease and end. However, this day came at last, thanks to a poor holy man, whose daughter had been stolen by the king.

This unfortunate man came to the prince's house to explain his grievances, and the prince swore that he would have him thrown into the fire if he did not leave his presence immediately. The man left with eyes full of tears, then, raising his hands to heaven and turning to the side of Mecca, he cried out: O my God, O Master, I ask you, who are near us, who see, who know and hear everything, to you who are the Dominator, I ask you to chew up this lecherous and perverse being who has benefited so long from your indifference and who, deluded by your kindness, has allowed himself to oppress a holy personage; accept my invocation and come to my aid when I implore you.

Now, that same day, the shî received the visit of two holy
بعد رجوعه. "after his return": the text does not indicate whether this refers to the moment when the shî Ali left Dienné to return to Songaï proper or whether it refers to a trip that this prince would have made to Dienné later.
A marginal note from mscr. A, introduced into the text by B, indicates that the ruins of this dwelling were known as mâdougou, a word that is equivalent in the Mandingo language to our phrase royal palace. The mscr. C interposes here an entire chapter relating to shî Ali, a chapter which is found verbatim in the Tarikh es-Soudân and which in some ways duplicates what precedes (see translation of the Tarikh es-Soudân, pp. 103-116).
personnages of the descendants of the môrı Haougâro, ancestor of the people of Môri-Koïra; one of them was called the môri Es-Sâdiq and the other the môri Djeïba. They were coming to complain about an injury that someone from his family had caused them, i.e. that is to say, the family of the shî Ali. As soon as he saw these two men, he gave the order to seize them and put them in chains, then to take them to an island and abandon them there: O my God, cried one of them, protect us from this man and destroy him before he can move from his place!- And, cried the other, let him not die in a state of Islam but in a state of infidelity! And the shî, who was at that time in a place in the country of Hâdjar called Konna1, perished the same day, struck by God with a sudden death.

As soon as his soldiers were sure of his death, they buried him on the spot, and no one has known since then where his tomb was located (God's curse be upon him!). The next day, his soldiers set out again without any of the inhabitants of the place in question knowing of his death ().

Some of his soldiers went to the island where the môri Es-Sâdiq and the môri Djeïba had been deported, removed the fetters from their feet and took them out of the island the very next day after the death of the shî. Praise be to Him who dispels all sorrows, who makes all the afflicted calm, and whose treasures are between a kaf and a noun, for when He wants something, He has only to say koun (be) and the thing is? This is how he makes the princes perish and frees the prisoners.
div.note: Or Gounna (قن). Perhaps this is Konna, a village southeast of Lake Débo, between the Bani and the mountainous cliff; perhaps it is another locality in the same region. The Tarikh es-Soudân causes the chl Ali to perish in a stream called Koni, on his return from an expedition to the Fulani of the Gourma, i.e., the Boucle du Niger,

The Arabic word koun, meaning "be," is composed of the two letters kaf (k) and noun (n): hence this kind of proverb saying that between the k and the n are included all the treasures that God can create.
div.p: The death of shî Ali took place in the month of moharrem by which the year 898 of the hegira [23 October - 21 November 1492] began.1 However, in the work entitled Dorer el-hisan fi akhbar ba'd moloủk es-Soûdan2 it is said that the death of shî Ali took place in the year 99 of the sixth century3. He had reigned 27 years, 4 months and 15 days.4

His son Aboubakar, nicknamed the shî Bâro, had accompanied him in this expedition5 and, as soon as the army, in its return march, had arrived at Bankeï6, it proclaimed Bâro in the place of his father, the second day of rebi II (January 21, 1493). But this does not agree with the account of the Dorer el-hisân, which says that the proclamation of Bâro took place in Diâga7: Please refer to this work.

The sheikh-el-islâm, the câdi Abouttsenâ Mahmoûd ben Omar ben Mohammed Aqît (God have mercy on him and show him his benevolence!) was born one year before the accession of the shî8; now, according to the account of our master Aboulabbas
On 15 moharrem 898 (November 6, 1492), according to the Tarikh es Soudin.
See note 1, page 83.
This would make 799, an error of one century: it often happens that authors who are not very attentive name a century after the initial number of the vintage, giving for example the name of the 8th century to the set of years whose vintage begins with8.
The shî Ali, having ascended the throne in 869 having died at the beginning of 898, reigned about 29 lunar years; the Tarikh es Soudân, which gives the same dates for his accession and death, makes him reign "27 or 28 years."
That is, in the expedition on whose return the shî Ali died.
بنكى in A, سنكى in B; we do not know which locality this is.
ذاغ Diâga or Diâ is a town in western Mâssina located on the arm of the Niger that is called the side branch of Diâga or Diâ. It is unlikely that this is where the son of shî Ali was proclaimed and there must have been, on the part of the copyist or the author, a misreading; the Tarikh es-Soudân has Aboubakar proclaimed at Denga (دنغ), a locality on the right bank of the Niger between Bourem and Gâo.
That is, of the shî Ali.
Ahmed-Bâba ben Ahmed ben El-Hâdj Ahmed, an account contained in his work entitled Kifayat el-moḥtâdj fî ma'rifat mâ laïsa fi'd-dîbâdj, this câdi is said to have been born in the year 868 [September 15, 1463-September 2, 1464).1

Among the main scholars and great characters of the Tekroûr who died at the time of shî Ali, there was the jurisconsult, the câdi môdibbo Qassim Dionkâssi2 and Sidi Yahya El-Andaloussi Et-Tâdelsi3, whose genealogy, well established, is as follows: Sidi Yahya ben Abderrahîm ben Abderrahmân Et-Tsa'âlebi ben Yahya El-Bekkaï ben El-Hassan ben Ali ben Abdallah ben () Abdeldjebbâr hen Temîm ben Hormoz ben Hâchim ben Qossaï ben Yoûssof ben Yoûcha' ben Ouerd ben Battâl ben Ahmed ben Mohammed ben 'Issa ben Mohammed ben El-Hassan ben Ali ben Aboutaleb (God be good to him and let us benefit from the consideration they all enjoy! ). It is said that Sidi Yahya was invested with the functions of câdi; at least this is what I read in a text written in the hand of a tâleb. There would be to mention still other characters who died during the lifetime of shî Ali.

Bâro, the son of this prince, had thus been invested with power; he had not yet reigned four months when the askia Mohammed ben Aboubakar, whose party was triumphing, received the support of God against shî Bâro, on the 2nd of the month of
The Tarikh es-Sudân also gives this reference, referring to the famous work of Amed-Bâba, in order to justify the date of 869 given for the advent of Ali. Since Ahmed-Bâba was still young at the time of the death of Mahmûd Kâti (1593 according to the Tarikh es-Sudan), the latter could not have had him as his master: it is therefore the grandson of Mahmûd Kâti who speaks here.
The reading of the last name (جنكاس) is doubtful as far as the vowels are concerned; the Tarikh es-Soudân speaks of this character, whom it makes die four years before the shî Ali (trad., p. 116).
This famous personage was the first imâm of the mosque of Timbuktu which still bears his name and which was built by Mohammed-Naddi during the lifetime of Sidi Yahya; the Tarikh es-Sudân speaks at length of this holy man, whom he causes to die in 868 (1463-64) (cf. trad., pp. 80-84).
djomâda the first1, in a place called Anfao2, where the two adversaries had stopped to gather their warriors. The meeting between Bâro and the askia Mohammed took place on 24 of the month of djomâda the second, which was a Monday; the battle was so violent and the combat so bloody that all believed their last hour had arrived; the Dendi-fâri Afoumba, who was standing by the shî and who was a man of the greatest courage, threw himself into the River and perished there. As for the askia Mohammed, he had with him the mansa Koûra4, who was Bara-koï5, but no other king of the Tekroûr nor of the Songaï6 had answered his call: however God (may he be praised! ) gave victory to the askia Mohammed and the Bâro shî fled to Diâga.
This is what the câdi Mahmoûd Kâti ben El-Hâdj El-Motaouakkel Kâti7 said.

The struggle did not begin between them until after the askia had sent the scholar, the saint, the pious Mohammed Toulé, that sherif whose genealogy is linked to the Beni-Medâs,
That is, on February 19, 1493, exactly one lunar month after the date given by the author for the proclamation of the shî Bâro; the four months just mentioned must therefore be counted from the death of the shî Ali and not from the investiture of Bâro.
انفع. The Tarikh es-Sudan calls this locality Ankoo (انكع) and places it in the neighborhood of Gâo.
So April 12, 1493; the Tarikh es-Sudân relates two battles that are said to have been fought at the same place between Bâro and Mohammed, the first on the 2nd of Jomada I and the second on the 14th of Jomada II (see Tarikh es-Sudan, Arabic text, page ٧١). The 14th of Jomada II began on a Monday and the 24th on a Thursday; the exact date must therefore be the 14th and not the 24th of Jomada II, i.e. the 2nd of April 1493.
Term meaning "king" in the Mandingo language; this was, as will be seen later, the title borne by the chiefs of the Bara.
That is, in Songai, chief of the Bara. The Bara is a province north of Lake Débo, on the right bank of the arm of the Niger which borrowed its name (the Bara-Issa or Bara River).
That is, from the Western Sudan, not from the Nigerian Sudan.
The entire end of this chapter, which is missing in mscr. A and B, is due to the pen of Mahmûd Kâti the ancestor, while what precedes it, from page 93, was probably written by the grandson.
to the shî Bâro to invite the latter to embrace Islam. The latter, who was then in a town called Anfao, absolutely refused. He was afraid for his sovereignty, as was natural for a king; so he was harsh in his words towards the scholar and the situation seemed so serious to him that he thought of putting the latter to death; but God, by his omnipotent will, turned him away from this plan. The scholar returned to the askia Muhammad and informed him of the refusal of the shî Bâro and of the way the latter had behaved towards him.

Then the askia Mohammed dispatched to the shî Bâro a second envoy, who was the learned, the pious, the virtuous, the author of miracles and marvelous deeds, the alfa Salih Diawara, of Wa'kuri origin (). This one went to the shî Bâro and transmitted to him the message of the prince, i.e. of the askia Mohammed. But this only increased the insolence of the shî, his obstinate resistance and his pride; so he received the second messenger even more harshly than the first.

He had then more than ten ministers, among them the mansa Mûsa, who was Bara-koï; he was then an old man, father of ten children. Each of these ministers commanded a special corps of troops. All of them had remained with the shî Bâro except one of them, the mansa Koûra1, who had fled to the prince, that is to say to the askia Mohammed, and had recognized him as sovereign. As for the Dirma-koï2 Sandi3, the Taraton-koï4, the Bani-koï5,
He was one of the sons of the mansa Mûsa,
That is, the chief of the Dirma, a province situated between the Issa-Ber and the Bara-lssa.
سندى. This word may be a proper name, or a title that would mean "the lord, the chief" in Songai.
ترتنكى. This is certainly a provincial chief, as with the other ministers, but we do not know which province is meant here; the reading of the word, moreover, is uncertain.
بنكى. Probably the chief of Bani, that is, of a province washed by the Bani between Dienné and Lake Débo.
"/>to the Kara-koï1, to the Dienné-koï and to the others of the ministers in question, each of whom commanded a large army, they had all remained with the shî Bâro.

One of these ministers, the Dirma-koë of whom we have just spoken, swore that he would not fail to kill the scholar Sâlih Diawara, an envoy of the askia prince, adding: "If you do not have this scholar put to death, the askia will not cease to dispatch envoys to you; if, on the contrary, you have him put to death, the askia will not continue to to send them to you". But God prevented him from carrying out this plan and the shî, addressing himself to Sâlih Diawara, said to him: "Return to the one who sent you; but, if a new messenger comes to me on his behalf, let the blood of this messenger fall on your head. Tell the askia who sent you that he should prepare himself for the fight that is going to take place between him and me; tell him that I do not accept his proposals and that I will never accept them."

The scholar Sâlih Diawara returned to the prince, reported to him the words of the shî Bâro and made known to him the dispositions of spirit of the latter and the energy with which the shî had refused before him to embrace Islamism. When Sâlih Diawara had informed the askia of what he had witnessed during his meeting with the shî Bâro, the prince gathered his council, composed of the ulama, the notables and the chiefs of his army, and he consulted them on the point of knowing what he should do: to engage in the fight with the shî Bâro or to send him a third envoy? All were of the opinion that he should send a third envoy who, by using diplomacy, would try to soften the shî; perhaps then God would bring this one back to the right way and make him embrace Islam.
div.note: كركى. The chief of Kara or Karadougou (or Kala), between Dienné and Sansanding.
div.p: It was then that the askia sent me, the humble believer, the alfa Kâti, to the shî. So I went to him and found him in the town of Anfao, which is near Gâo. I gave him the message of the askia, prince of the believers, and I spoke to him with as much courtesy as possible, as the askia El-Hâdj Mohammed, prince of the believers, had recommended to me. I spoke kindly to him in the hope that God would bring him back to the right path. But he refused to listen to my advice, became angry, ordered the drum to be beaten immediately and began to gather his troops, scolding and storming in order to intimidate me, while I applied to myself the words of the poet: "I will ensure today by my death the triumph over the cross and its worshippers".
At the same time, his troops massed around him like a mountain range (), raising clouds of dust that made the day seem like night, and began to shout loudly, swearing that blood would flow freely.

Then I returned and told him what had happened. The askia El-Hâdj Mohammed, prince of the believers, immediately made his preparations, ordering the drum to be beaten and his troops to gather around him immediately. All his men swore to remain faithful to him until death.

Then he mounted his horse and, at the head of his victorious army, rode in the direction of shî Bảro. The two troops met on Monday, the 24th of the month of Jomâda II. Between the time when the askia, prince of the believers, had sent his [first] message to the shî Bảro and the time of وانصر على الصليب وعابديه البوم اهلك
the meeting of their two armies, fifty-two days had passed.

A violent battle ensued between the two troops. God came to the aid of the askia against the shî Bâro, whose soldiers were routed and suffered such terrible losses that they believed that they were all going to perish and that the end of the world had arrived. The Dendi-fâri Afoumba, who was next to the shî Bâro and who was a very brave man, threw himself that day into the River, where he died.

As for El-Hâdj Mohammed, he had with him the mansa Kûra, son of the mansa Mûsa, of which it was spoken before, but he was accompanied by none of the other kings of Tekroûr nor of Songaï, none having answered his call except for this one.

When God had routed the troops of shî Bâro, he fled alone to Ayorou1, where he remained until his death, while the very fortunate, the very orthodox2 seized power and became the prince of the believers and the khalifa of the Muslims.

Thus God made the askia El-Hâdj Mohammed inherit all the territory of the Bâro shî, a territory which extended from Kanta to Sibiridougou3, and this prince found himself becoming the master of twenty-four tribes which consisted of slaves of the shî and not of free men reduced to slavery.4
div.note: اير Ayorou is located on the Niger at the mouth of the Gorouol, between Koûkiya and Tillabéry. An earlier passage carried that the Bâro shî had taken refuge in Diâga, which is less likely. It is possible, however, that the Diâga in question is a locality close to Ayorou.
That is, the askia El-Hâdj Mohammed.
See note 1, page 82.

The author means that these were tribes or castes of servile origin, which formed, as it were, the human domain of the crown under the shî and then under the askia, and not noble tribes which the shî or their successors would have conquered and reduced to a state of captivity.
div.p: We shall enumerate, God willing, the names of these tribes. Three of them were among the pagan tribes of the Bambara. The first was related to the descendants of Diara Koré Boukar, while the second had its origin in Ngaratibi1 and the third came from Kassambara. (The shî Bâro had inherited these tribes from his father the shî Ali, who had inherited them in the same way from the shî Souleïmân-Dâma, to whom some give the name of Dândi. In the same way the latter had inherited them from the shî Balma, this one from the shî Mohammed-Fâri, this one from the shî Mohammed-Koûkiya: In the same way the latter had inherited them from the shî Mâdogo, who, himself, had seized them on the Malli-koï .

These tribes in fact had become vassals of the Malli-koï at the time when the ancestors of the latter had increased their power and after having held the [first] Malli-koï themselves under their authority. Later, God having brought down the power of the Malli-koï to the benefit of the shî Mâdogo, the latter ravaged the empire of the Malli-koï, took their children into captivity, seized all their property, and took away from them the property of these twenty-four tribes.

As for the () three of these tribes (of which we have spoken above), they were among the domestic serfs of the Malli-koï. Since they belonged to the Malli-koï, the custom was that none of the men of these tribes could marry until the king had given 40,000
See note 9, page 20.
See note 1, page 21; the text here bears the spelling كسم برم.
The Arabic word نلاد, used by the author, refers to hereditary property long owned by the same family and also to cattle or slaves born in the house. It responds exactly to the Sudanese expressions which we vulgarly translate as hut captives and which apply to the descendants of slaves born in the master's house and forming part of the family property.
cowries1 to the in-laws of the future, in order to prevent the wife or her children from claiming freedom and to make it clear that they and their own children would remain the property of the Malli-koï.

These three tribes in question descended from a common primitive stock, [their ancestors] having had the same father, called Béma Tâsso, and the same mother, named Arbaa Kalé, so that they were all three brothers of father and mother. A quarrel broke out between them about a woman that all three wanted to marry, and they came to hate each other so much that they ceased to consider themselves of the same blood. They derived their origin from Kassambara and their village, which was called Niani, was part of the territory of the Malli and was the capital of the Malli-koï.2

From the time of the Malli-koï, and since these tribes belonged to them, they were bound to an annual payment of forty cubits [of land to be developed] by each couple, husband and wife; so it was until these tribes had passed into the hand of the shî. In the time of the shî, from the first of these rulers who was their master until the last, that is to say, until the shî Ali, the service was thus regulated: the people were gathered together in groups of a hundred, men and women together, and the shî made each group measure two hundred cubits on the ground; the people then gathered to the sound of drums and flutes and ploughed the land for him, shouting in the manner of ploughmen while the drums were beaten; when the time of harvest came, the produce of these fields was divided by the shî among his
Small shells used as currency in the Sudan; their current value varies from 600 to 1,000 for a franc.
See note 2, page 66.
soldiers, and, if the harvest was nil, he struck the people with an imposition and made them responsible for it.

When the askia Muhammad had become the master of these tribes, he fixed the benefit thus: every year, at harvest time, he sent a man from his entourage to collect the produce of the harvest; if anyone was able to give ten measures of flour1, they took it from him; if anyone could give twenty measures, they took it from him, and so on up to thirty measures, without exceeding this figure, which was the limit that was never crossed, even if the taxpayer would have been able to provide a thousand measures. The askia Mohammed also took from these people some of their children and used them to buy horses.2

As for the fourth of the twenty-four tribes of which we have spoken, it was the tribe of the people called Tyindikèta (), from a word which, in their language, means cutter of grass.3 Their work, from the time of the Malli-koï until the time of the shî, consisted in cutting grass for the horses. When they passed into the hands of the askia Mohammed, the latter maintained this custom, for he found that they were good only for tending horses. However the askia Mohammed imposed a new obligation on them, enjoining the adults to make dugouts which the young boys employed as grooms would make use of for the service of the horses.4 The askia Mohammed did indeed take from this tribe a number of young boys to whom he had his horses groomed, wherever he found them from Gâo to Sibiridougou.
div.note: The author uses the word غت, plural افتات. Perhaps this is the equivalent of the songai word fadda, which refers to a measure corresponding to about 120 liters.
Using these children as currency.
See note 2, page 20.
Presumably to go cut the aquatic grass called bourgou, which grows in the flood zone of the Niger and is said to provide excellent fodder.
div.p: The fifth tribe was the Zendji1. Each Zendji from the Kanta to the Sibiridougou, also owed a royalty which was collected each year at the time of the fall of the waters of the River. It consisted, for those who were able to provide them, of ten packages of dried fish; for those who could provide only nine, it was of nine; for those who could provide only seven, it was of seven, and so on until only one packet for those who could provide only one, each one paying according to his means, without however that the royalty could never exceed ten packets.
Whenever anyone came to the prince to ask for a boat, he provided it by taking from the people of that tribe a dugout canoe with its crew.

The askia Mohammed in fact had taken and reserved these people for his service and that of the people of his house, not allowing anyone to employ them or sell them. He reserved this right for himself and his children, but made an exception for the Hasanid sheriff Es-Seqli, who was a descendant of Ali. When this sheriff went to Gâo and found the askia Muhammad there, the latter gave him all the descendants of a Zendji called Faran-Taka2, who were at that time 2,700 in number.3 The prince made this gift to the sheriff because he belonged to the descendants of the Prophet (God shower his blessings on him and grant him salvation!) and to show his affection for him. In the biography of the askia Mohammed, we will talk in detail, God willing, about
See note 2 on page 38. It seems that the people to whom the author gives this name were mainly fishermen and boatmen (present-day Kurtei, Sorko, Bozo and Somono).
فرن تك. This character, who has remained legendary among the Songai, was the son of the famous Faran, ancestor of a clan of Sorko that still bears his name today.
In an earlier passage, the author has already related this anecdote, but only estimating the number of Zendji given to the sheriff at 1,700.
this liberality, as well as of the division of the Zendji which were attributed partly to this sheriff and partly to other characters.

The sixth tribe consisted of the people called Arbi1. These provided the servants of the prince, the members of his household and his servants; their daughters were employed in the service of his wives. They also farmed for him and his children. The young men of the tribe escorted him in arms, marching before and behind him in war as in ordinary times; he employed them as messengers for his special missions. The people of this tribe were exclusively attached to the service of the prince and that is why they were not required to pay royalties in kind.

As for the seventh, eighth, ninth, tenth and eleventh tribes, which were tribes of blacksmiths, they were the tribes of the Diam-Téné, the Diam-Wali, the Sorobanna, [of the Komé] and of the Samatséko. These five tribes were all descended from the same father. This father was a blacksmith, () a slave of the Christians, who had fled from the islands of the Atlantic Ocean and had come to Koûkiya, capital of the shî, at the time of the shî Mohammed-Fâri. This slave, whose name was Boukar, married a slave of Nâna-Salam, mother of the aforementioned shî. This slave, who was called Matabala, gave him five male children: Téné, who was the father of the Diam-Téné tribe; Wali, who was the father of the Diam-Wali tribe; Sorobanna, who was the father of the Sorobanna tribe; Komé, who was the father of the Komé tribe, and Samatséko, who was the father of the Samatséko tribe, these tribes attaching their genealogies to their fathers.3
div.note: See note 5, page 21.
See above, pages 20 and 21. The name of the Kome has been omitted here by the author, who names only four tribes out of five; but this name is reproduced a little later.
See note 3, page 42.
div.p: The father of these five children was a cruel, rude, depraved, authoritarian, ignorant, tyrannical and violent man. He and his sons engaged in robbery, cutting off roads, murdering people, taking them prisoner or robbing them. Complaints about them were brought to the then reigning shî, who sent a small troop against them with the order to kill the father and seize the children, the latter being his slaves since they were the sons of one of his slaves. The father was killed and the five sons were brought to the shî, who distributed them among different cities to prevent them from meeting again and repeating their misdeeds. Each of them had numerous descendents.
The dues of these five tribes, from the time of the shî until the time of the askia Muhammad, were one hundred spears and one hundred arrows per each family per year.

As for the twelfth tribe, which was that of the Kurunkoi4 that one meets from Gâo to the city of Fâni2, it originated in the country of Sôma , which borders their [present] territory without being however very close to it4. It is an offshoot of the Samatséko tribe, because it descends from the sons of the daughter of Samatséko.
We shall speak further on, if it please God, in recounting the biography of the askia Mohammed, of the rest of the twenty-four tribes, those just mentioned forming only half of them.
div.note: See note 4, page 21. The word is here spelled as follows: kaf with vowel ou, ra with vowel approximating ou, noun without vowel, kuf with vowel or very short and ya without vowel.
فنى. We do not know where this locality is, whose name moreover could be read in another way.
سوم. Perhaps it is a province between the upper Niger and the valley of the Senegal.
Translation uncertain; it is possible that a gap exists in the manuscript.
div.p: In the year in which all the events related above took place,1 the askia Mohammed was 50 years old, the alfa Sâlih Diawara was 49 years old, Mohammed Toulé was 26 years old, and I was at that time a young man, 26 years old, and I was at that time a young man of 25 years old. As for Mahmoûd ben Omar ben Mohammed Aqît, he was then 28 years old.
div.note: That is, the year 898 of the hegira (1492-1493), in which the shî Baro was defeated by the askia Muhammad.
This allows us to assign the year 1468 as the approximate date of birth of Mahmûd Kâti, the author of this narrative.

div.head: Chapter VI
Biography of the askia Muhammad
div.p: The following is the biography of the prince of the believers, the sultan of the Muslims, the askia Abu-Abdullah Mohammed ben Aboubakar.

His father's nickname was Arloûm and he belonged to the clan of the Silla1 which is said to have originated from Tôro2. As for his mother, her name was Kassaï and she was the daughter of Koura-koï-Boukar. We have seen people who trace his mother's genealogy back to the descendants of Djâbir ben Abdallah, one of the Ansâr, but it would be out of place to go into further details on this subject3.

It is impossible to enumerate his virtues and qualities, such as his excellent policy, his benevolence towards his subjects and his concern for the poor. There is no one like him among those who preceded him, nor among those who came after him. He had a great affection for the Ulema, the holy people and the tâlebs. He
One of the leading Soninke clans.
One of the provinces of Senegal's Foûta (Podor province), where members of the Silla clan are still found, which also has representatives in the Gâo region.
That is, "chief of Koura"; Koura is the name of a large island formed by the Niger before arriving at Tombouctou.
The mscr. C, which does not contain the preceding sentence, instead gives the complete genealogy of Koura-koï Boukar, as follows: Boukar ben Ali ben Abdallah ben El-Hassan ben Abderrahmân ben Idris ben Ya'qoùb ben Ishaq ben Youssof ben El Hassan ben Abdelaziz ben Sofần ben Sâlih ben Louaï ben Mohammed El-Yemeni ben Aboubekr ben Ali ben Moûssa ben Hosseïn ben Eliâs ben Abdâbir ben Abdallah El-Ansari (may God be pleased with him!).
used to give a lot of alms and perform, in addition to the prescribed duties, supererogatory acts of devotion. He was a most intelligent and wise man. He was very considerate of the Ulema and gave them slaves and wealth generously in order to secure the interests of the Muslims and to help them in their submission to God and in the practice of worship. He did away with all that the shîs had introduced in the way of blameworthy innovations, iniquities and bloody cruelties. He established the religion on the most solid foundations. He freed from slavery all those who could claim their rights to freedom and returned to their owners all the property of which the shî had robbed them. He restored the religion by instituting câdis and imâms: may God reward him for his zeal in the name of Islamism! Thus he appointed a câdi in Timbuktu, a câdi in the town of Dienné and a câdi in every town in his territory that had one, from the Kanta to Sibiridougou.

Having disembarked one day in the town of Kabara, as he was heading at the head of his troops towards the Soûra-Bantamba, he mounted his horse preceded by his servant Ali Foulan who carried his sword, and left after the prayer of the sunset, having with him nobody other than this Ali Foulan. When he arrived at the place where the people of Tombouctou make the prayer today on feast days, he said to Ali Foulan, "Do you know where the house of the câdi Mahmoud ben Omar is?" - "Certainly," replied Ali. - "Go then to the house of this câdi," resumed the askia, "and tell him that I am here alone and that he should come and join me there alone." Then he held his horse by tightening the reins and Ali Foulan left.

The latter found the sheikh, that is the câdi Mahmoûd, stationed at the door of his house and surrounded, as usual, by a number of people. Ali Foulan
transmitted to him the message of the askia Mohammed and the câdi, deferring to the invitation, only went home to take his staff and set out with Ali, dismissing all those who wanted to follow him, to go alone to the askia Mohammed. Arrived near this one, he greeted him and kissed his generous hands. Ali Foulan seized the horse's noseband and took it away, after having received the prince's order to keep away all the indiscreet.

Then the askia said to the câdi, after the complete exchange of polite formulas and greetings: "I had sent messengers bearing my instructions: did you fulfill my orders in Tombouctou? No, you sent my messengers away, preventing them from carrying out my decisions. Did not the Malli-koï rule over Tombouctou? Certainly yes, replied the sheikh, he ruled over this city. - Wasn't there at that time a câdi in Tombouctou? - There was, Mahmoûd replied. - Are you better than this câdi or was this câdi better than you? He was better than me and more illustrious. - "Did this câdi," resumed the askia, "prevent the emperor of Malli from exercising his authority in Tombouctou?" - "No, he did not prevent it." "Have not the Tuareg," continued the askia, "been the masters of this city?" - "They were." "Wasn't there at that time a câdi in Tombouctou?" "There was." "Are you better than that câdi or was that câdi better than you?" - "He was better than me," said the sheikh, "and was more illustrious." - ""Was not the shî then the ruler of Timbuktu? Was he indeed the ruler of it? -Was there not then a câdi in the city?" - "There was." -"Did he fear God more than you, or is it you who fear God more than he and are more illustrious?" —
Timbuktu, after being part of the empire of the Malli from 1325 to 1433, was occupied by the Tuareg from 1433 to 1468.
Chî Ali took Tombouctou in 1468 and annexed it to the kingdom of Songai.
"No, it was he who feared God more than I did and was superior to me." - "Did all these câdis prevent the rulers from exercising their authority in Toubouctou , from executing or forbidding what they pleased, from levying taxes or contributions there?" - "They never prevented them from doing so and they never obstructed their wishes." "Well," said the askia, "why do you prevent me from acting and why do you obstruct me? Why, when I send messengers to carry out my instructions, do you push them away, hit them? why do you order them to be chased out of the city? what business is it of yours and why do you act in this way?"

To these words, the sheikh (God have mercy on him!) replied: "Have you forgotten or do you pretend to forget the day when you came to my house and took me by the foot and by my clothes and said to me: 'I have come to place myself under your protection and to entrust you with the responsibility of the people? I have come to place myself under your protection and to entrust you help me and hold me by the hand so that I do not fall into hell.' This is the cause that made me chase your envoys and reject your orders." "I had forgotten it, by God! exclaimed the askia, but now it comes back to my memory and you are right. By God, you deserve to be rewarded, because you prevented a misfortune. May God keep you as a barrier between me and the fires of hell! I had irritated the Almighty, but I ask his forgiveness and I return to him. Even today I trust in you and cling to you. Keep your situation, may God maintain it for you, and protect me always!"

Then the askia kissed the hand of the sheikh, took leave of him, got back on his horse and returned to his steps happy and satisfied, making wishes for the sheikh to live long so that he himself could give up his soul to God before the sheikh (God have mercy on him!).

If you consider these words of the askia Muhammad, you
will see that he was a man of pure heart, believing in God and his prophet. What admirable figures these two were! Praise be to God who raised them above the common! It is to him alone indeed that they owe their merits.

The askia Muhammad had been in power for two years and five months when the ninth century ended. It was during the last year of the century1 that he seized Diâga.2 Having taken 500 masons from that city, he took 400 of them to Gâo for his personal service, with all their instruments; these had, at that time, a chief called Karamogho. As for the other hundred masons, he gave them to his brother Amar-Komdiago.

It is during the same year that Amar-Komdiâgo was invested of the dignity of kanfâri3; he was the first to carry this title, which did not exist before, whereas the titles of balamâ4 and Bengafarma existed since the time of the chî.
div.note: The text literally bears "during this year"; this is probably the year with which the ixth century of the hegira ended, i.e., the year 900 (October 2, 1494 to September 28, 1495). The Tarikh es-Sudan places the capture of Diâga at the end of the year 899. - If Muhammad had indeed been reigning for two years and five months when the year 900 ended, it is appropriate to place his accession at the end of redjeb 898, i.e., around May 18 1493; this agrees quite well with the date assigned by the author to Muhammad's victory over Bâro (12 or 2 April 1493).
See note 7, page 100.

The kanfâri was the first dignitary of the kingdom under the askia; his title seems to belong to the Mandingo language, in which it is said to mean "chief of the summit"; the author often gives the holder of the office of kanfâri the name of Kourmina-fâri, as the government of the Kourmina fell within the kanfâri's remit (see note 4, page 13).
The balamâ () was, it seems, something like the steward general of the kingdom; we do not know the exact etymology of this title, which seems to belong to the Mandingo language.

This word (spelled بنكبرم, in A and in B, which also gives the variant ) means "governor of Benga or Binga," i.e., of the province east of the Bara and Dirma that contains the lakes on the right bank of the Niger upstream from Tombouctou.
div.p: In the course of the year 902 [September 9, 1496 -August 29, 1497] the city of Tendirma was built2. The askia Mohammed had indeed given the kanfâri orders to build for himself a capital. After searching, in accordance with the prince's advice, among the region of the islands3 and among the desert region, Amar arrived at Tendirma, whose location appealed to him. This place was formerly the home of a group of Jews4 whose tombs and wells are still found there today. When the people of Amar's retinue saw these wells, of which there were then 333, both inside the city and in the vicinity, and when they saw the remarkable way in which these wells had been dug and laid out, they were filled with wonder.

The following was reported by one of our contemporaries living in Môri-Koïra, the môri Es-Sâdiq, son of the jurisconsult môri (Mama) son of the jurisconsult môri Mâmaka son of the jurisconsult môri Haougâro.

He told us that he had heard his father, talking with people of his generation, tell that he had the following story from his grandfather. It was not on the order of the shî that the Jews had dug these wells nor because they had many herds, but because they cultivated vegetables from which they profited, the traders buying them for considerable sums, and because the water of these wells was better suited to their vegetables than the water of the River; he indeed who watered his vegetables with
Literally: "In that year which was the year 902."
This name is spelled in the text generally , but also from and ; the local pronunciation is Tendirma or Tindirma.
That is, the lake region.
"Beni-Israel" in the text.
the water of the River did not obtain products as sought after nor of as beautiful appearance as the one who watered them with the water of the wells: such was the cause for which they had dug these wells.

Some of these wells were 140 cubits deep, others were 200 cubits deep and some were only 60 to 100 cubits deep. Whenever the depth was less than 60 cubits, the water was not suitable for vegetables ().

At that time their city was so large that some of the inhabitants, when they wanted to go to wash their clothes, had to leave immediately after noon, taking with them their evening meal, and walk at a fast pace until sunset or almost until then, only then to reach the place where they could wash their clothes, while others had to walk only about twenty paces to go from the wall of their house to the edge of the water.1

At that time seven princes reigned in the city, all of them descendants of the kings of the Jews, namely Jebroût ben Hichâm, Dzoulyemen ben Abdelhakim, Zeïr2 ben Salâm, Abdellatif ben Souleïmân, Mâlik ben Ayyoûb, Fadl ben Mizâr and Ghalib ben Yoûssof, Each of them had under his command a large army and each prince had wells determined for him and his troop. Whoever made a mistake and watered his vegetables with water from a well belonging to another prince than his own, had to compensate the prince who owned the well, whether the mistake was made by a free man or a slave. Each prince had 12,000 horsemen; as for the foot soldiers, that is, those who went on foot, they could not have been counted or enumerated.
div.note: The author evidently means that the city extended from the water's edge to a distance of half a day's walk away from the River.
Or Zeïd.
div.p: This is the way in which they dug wells. Immediately after drilling a well and removing the earth from it, they would mason the walls with clay and stones, then they would bring bundles of a wood such as teiber-teiber1 and arrange them in the middle of the well; then they would bring jars of bulanga2 and spread them over the whole, then they would set fire to it: the material would then melt, looking like cast iron3; the whole thing was then left to cool, and water was poured over it. Some of the ashes in the well were then removed, but some were left behind.
