The drilling of these wells required a considerable expense, but in the whole of the Tekroûr, there were no vegetables comparable to those of the city of which we have just spoken. Such is the information which was reported to us.

However Amar had arrived in this place with the intention of building Tendirma. This city was so called because the kanfâri, at the moment of his arrival, found no one there except one Sorko, called Tendi, married to a woman () named Marma, and the names of these two individuals were joined together to form the name of the city, which is composed of Tendi and Marma4.

When Amar-Komdiago saw this Sorko, he asked him what had brought him there, and then he said to him: "What is your name and what tribe are you from?" The man answered him with these words:
. We do not know what this tree is, whose name seems to belong to the Songai language and may mean "big foot-big foot" in that idiom.
This is the Songai name for shea oil or butter.
The stones used to mason the walls were most likely iron ore.
Some people make the word Tendirma come from Berber and give it the etymology ten-Dirma "the place of Dirma ". A large number of localities in the Sudan bear the name Tendirma or Tindirima, which means in Mandingo "on the small hill".
"My name is Tissiman, but my children here call me Tendi because they heard their mother call me that.1 As for my tribe, it is that of the Zendji of Tembo2, which is an island located between Gâo and the Dendi3. Now, at that time, his children were eighteen in number, including eleven girls and seven boys.
When Amar asked him if the Zendji of Tembo were free or slaves, the man answered: "They are not free men, they are slaves of Sherif Moulaï Ahmed, who resides in the city of Marrakech3".

"How many years have you been here?" "For thirty-five years," he replied, "all my children were born here, except for the eldest, Aïch-Tissim4." "Did you find someone here when you settled here?"" "I found only an old slave who was very old, whose hair was so white that it looked red, and who was the last survivor of the Jews' entourage. I stayed here with him for three years, after which he died in my arms." - "Did you ask him for information about this city?" - the Sorko replied ; "I asked him what he ate, what the name of the town was and what his name was
Tendi or Tindi may be a nickname meaning in Songai "the heavy one" or in Mandingo "hill,".
here. We are not sure of the transcription; the Hourst map has an island named Dembou between the mouth of the Sirba and the town of Say.
The prince who ruled in Marrakesh at this time (late fifteenth century) was the Merinid sultan Moulaſ Ahmed, who succeeded Moulaſ Said around 1895 and preceded Moulaſ En-Nasser.
The reading of this name is doubtful; perhaps it should read "Aich ben نسم Tissiman"; the latter word is written first comw, then not and then
It is known that, in blacks who have reached extreme old age, the hair changes from white to red, at least at the tips.
Literally "who was one of the remnants of the band of Beni-Israel".
himself. [He told me that] the name of the town was Bâko1, like his own name, that the name of the nearby lake was Fati2, and that (Fati was) the primitive name [of this localityl3'; he also told me that a slave of the genie species, freed by his master, brought him food whenever he was hungry, and he told me various things which I have partly forgotten."

However, Tissiman, having offered hospitality to Amar, served him fresh fish () to eat, and during the stay that Amar and his people made with him, which lasted nine days, his guests lived on fish, so much so that they were satiated.

Then the construction of the capital [of the kanfâri] was begun. From the research we have done on the history and chronology of this period, it appears that it was was then in the year 902 [September 2, 1496 - August 29, 1497]. 1497). The number of masons employed at the beginning was exactly one hundred; they were directed by a man named Ouahab Bari4.

They had been working on the construction for twenty-five days, when an envoy from his brother the askia Mohammed arrived at Amar, ordering him to go to him. As the walls of Amar's palace were not yet finished, the askia Mohammed enjoined the balamâ Mohammed-Koreïs and the Bengafarma Ali-Kindânkangaï to go to Tendirma and see to the completion of the construction
بعك. We thought we should transcribe by Báko, which means in Mandingo back of the river.
Lake Fati does indeed flow into the Niger at Tendirma.
The text reads: واسم البلد فاسمه بعك واسم بحيرتها فت واسم سابق
The translation is questionable.
برى. The word bari means "mason" in the Mandingo language.
حمد كرى, meaning, in Songai "Mohammed the white, light-skinned Mohammed".
of the walls of this palace; those in charge of this construction were Armayizzi1 and his brother the bâr-koï2 Boukar the Zaghrâni, both sons of the Dendi-fâri.

However, the kanfâri having gone to Gâo to join his brother, the latter installed him in his place and conferred on him the lieutenancy of the kingdom. Then the askia Muhammad began to make his preparations to perform the pilgrimage and go to visit the sacred temple of God, the tomb of the Prophet (peace be upon him!) and the tombs of his Companions (may God be pleased with them!). He had the money and equipment for the journey collected, sending orders to all parts of his territory to bring him food and supplies. Then he set out for the pilgrimage in the month of safar of the year 903 [September 29-October 27, 1497], after having been given 300,000 gold coins which he had taken from the honest khatîb4 Omar and which came from the part of the
Or Armizi, according to the vocalization of mscr. B.
and according to the mscr. A. This title seems to mean in Songai "chief of the exchange"; no doubt it referred to a kind of minister of commerce, unless one wants to read bari-koï, which would mean "chief of the horses, chief of the cavalry". One would be tempted to think of the Mandingo word bari "mason," but we do not think this word passed into the Songai language, and, on the other hand, the use of the suffix koï indicates that we are dealing with a Songaſ word.
The year is indicated only by mscr. A and B, which do not contain the preceding or following passage and replace them with this one paragraph: "In the third year of the xth century (of the hegira), the askia Muhammad set out on the pilgrimage, taking with him the Bara-koï, i.e., the mansa Koûra. Among those who set out with the askia were Yâyi Kato Ouakâra and white chiefs (korei), who were four in number and all four of them made a procession for him; among his companions on the pilgrimage were in addition eight hundred men (escorts) and seven jurisconsults from his capital. He had brought to Gâo his brother the kanfâri Amar to act as his interim and had conferred on him the lieutenancy of the kingdom, and that before the completion of the construction of the walls of the palace of the kanfâri Amar; so he had enjoined the balamâ Mohammed-Koreï and the Benga farma Ali-Kindânkangaſ to go to Tendirma, etc.," up to and including the words, "sons of the Dendi-fâri."
This word refers in Arabic to the one who gives the sermon at the main Friday prayer.
treasure of the shî Ali entrusted to the custody of this personage; as for the sums remaining in the palace of the shî, buried underground or hidden in chests, they were considerable.

He took with him eight hundred men of the army, among whom was his son the askia Moûssa, the hou-kokoreï-koï1 Ali Foulan, Yâyi Kato Ouakâra2 and of the white chiefs who were four in number, and who, all four, made for him a procession4, as well as the mansa Koûra ben Moûssa, who was Bara-koï and to whom the askia Mohammed had given the command of the province of Fara5 at the moment when God had helped him to triumph over the shî Bâro.

He also had with him seven of the jurisconsults of his capital, namely: the alfâ Sâlih Diawara, then the môri Mohammed Haougâro, who was then an old man advanced in age, then the alfa Mohammed Toulé, then Gâo-Zakaria, whose ethnic nickname was derived from Sanafa6, then the môri Mohammed, whose ethnic nickname was derived from
See note 3, page 6; this word means "chief of the palace eunuchs" in Songai.
Ouakâra may be a nickname, but this word can also be read "and Kâra" (وكار in the text) and refer to another character.
افيال كرى We think that these are chiefs of Tuareg groups; the word koreï means "white" in Songaï, but it also means "district", so that it could mean "chiefs of the district". As for the word افيال, it usually refers to the provincial chiefs of Yemen who were subject to the authority of the Himyarite tobba, but it is used several times in the Tarikh el-fettâch with the meaning of "chiefs."
This phrase, from "who were," appears only in the paragraph of mscr. A and B cited above in the note.
فر. The lack of vowels makes the reading of this word doubtful and prevents its identification. It could also be read فى (697), which in Songai means "the confluence,"
That is, "Zakaria of Gâo, so called because he came from "Sanafa"; this last word (die), whose vocalization is not indicated, must have This last word ( سنفة ), whose vocalization is not indicated, must have been the name of a district of Gâo ( see note 6, page 25).
Ténen-kou1, then the câdi Mahmoûd Niédobogho2 and finally myself, that is to say, Mahmoûd Kâti.

The account of his journey contains marvelous things which testify to our eyes of the favor with which God had showered this prince as well as the two jurisconsults (mentioned above), the alfa Sâlih Diawara and the alfa Mohammed Toulé.

One day while he was walking accompanied by his retinue, he arrived at a vast oasis () situated between Alexandria and Cairo and spent the night there with his troops. When midnight came, the alfa Sâlih Diawara, who had gone out alone to perform supererogatory prayers in a remote place, suddenly he heard a loud noise of voices; he went to the side of the voices and, when he was close to them, he saw lamps around which tâlebs belonging to the race of genies were reciting the Koran. Having gone around the group, he discovered that they were the companions of the genie Chamharoûch who were returning with him from the pilgrimage and that Chamharoûch was standing in the middle of them, while these tâlebs of the race of genies were turning towards him to recite the Koran. The alfa Sâlih Diawara went to the side of Chamharoûch and, when he arrived near him, he addressed him the Muslim greeting and shook his hand. All the group then began to return the greeting to the alfa and to shake his hand.

The voices, having been raised on this occasion, were heard by the alfa Mohammed Toulé, who went out himself to make supererogatory prayers. Having recognized in the midst of the voices that of the alfa Sâlih Diawara, he feared that the latter had quarreled with someone from the suite of the askia Mohammed, and he went to their side. When he arrived near them, he recognized the troop of the genius Chamharoûch
The word, written here is given above with the spelling (see note 7, page 25).
Or "Niandobogho"; see note 8, page 25.
and the alfa Sâlih Diawara who, standing by Chamharoûch, was addressing questions to him. He then came forward and greeted Chamharoûch and his companions and sat down to talk with them.

While they were talking, Moûssa, son of the alfa Sâlih Diawara, came out in his turn; he was then a child of six years. He heard his father's voice and went to the side from which it came. Arriving near the group, he recognized his father and the alfa Mohammed Toulé in the middle of the genies who formed the escort of the genie Chamharoûch and he sat down near his father.

At this moment Chamharoûch, addressing the two jurisconsults, said to them: "Who are you? - We are, they answered, people of the entourage of the prince of the Believers, the askia Mohammed; he left his home to accomplish the pilgrimage and we accompanied him for the same purpose. Chamharoûch then congratulated (Sâlih) Diawara and said, "The askia Mohammed is a holy man. I heard from the Prophet (God shower his blessings on him and grant him salvation!) that there would be twelve Khalifs, all of them from Qoreish, and I think that the askia Muhammad is one of them. Ten of them have already lived, there are still two to come and probably he is the eleventh; when the last one, will come during the 13th century [of the Hegira]1. The Prophet (blessings and salvation be upon him!) told me that I would live until the ninth century, that I would be the contemporary of the eleventh Khalifa, who would be the judge between genies and men, and that I should expect to die then. - So you saw the Prophet (God shower his blessings on him
The tenth century of the Hegira runs from the year 1786 to the year 1883 CE.
That is, until the end of the century that had just ended, since askia Muhammad had left for the pilgrimage in 903 A.H.
() and grant him salvation!)? they asked him. - "Yes," he replied, "and I have received his teachings." This good news filled the jurisconsults with joy.

In the meantime, a slave genius appeared before them and said: "One of your shepherds hit one of our young servants to the point that he lost consciousness, and therefore we appeal to the law against you. How, exclaimed the jurisconsult alfa Sâlih Diawara, would one of our shepherds have hit one of your servants, while you are invisible to us? -- "The young servant," replied the slave, "had taken the form of a serpent. But then Chamharoûch, chief of the geniuses, spoke and said: "The blood of one who has left his primitive form to metamorphose cannot be avenged".
Thereupon the jurisconsults rose, took leave of the genies and went to join their fellow travelers.

The caravan had spent two nights in this place when one of its members named Mohammed, koî-idié of Songaï1, who had belonged to the entourage of the shî and had committed many iniquities, died. When they got into line to make the prayer on the deceased, Moûssa, son of the alfa Sâlih, was standing, among the crowd, and the divine favor of which he was the object was manifested to our eyes. As he was near his father, he said to him: "O my father, behold, the angels are taking away the deceased from among us, so that only an empty stretcher remains in our hands! Now no one had seen this but him, and his father began to say to him, "Be quiet, O my little child!" Thus it was found that, from a young age, he had the gift of second sight.
div.note: That is, "prince of a royal family of Songai"; the term koï-idié () means in Songai "son of a chief" and is applied to characters descended from the ancient native kings of the country.
div.p: It was the day after that day that the divine favor of which our master and friend was the object, the one whose mouth was unceasingly occupied in reciting orations, the eminent, the pious, the devout, the ascetic, the friend of God the most high, the loyal jurisconsult, the alfa Salih Diawara, was manifested to us, as well as the one enjoyed by the Hassanid sheriff, the jurisconsult versed in lexicology, morphology and syntax and possessing a thorough knowledge of what concerns the Companions of the Prophet, the friend of God the most high Mohammed Toulé, as well as the one with which was filled the askia Muhammad, the equitable imâm, the father of orphans, widows, the poor and the weak, the protector of the scholars.

As for the alfa Sâlih Diawara, this is how the divine favor of which he was the object was manifested to us. We had left the place mentioned above and had been travelling forcibly for three days, when, on the third day, a wind began to blow so hot and violent that, in the whole caravan, only those whose faith was strong retained the hope of escaping death. All the water in the skins dried up, so that not a drop remained. The thirst having become so great for everyone that they suffered more than the wind, the skins were opened, but nothing was found, which increased the general despair.

The troop having been obliged to halt because of the violence of the wind, the askia Mohammed, prince of the believers, gave orders to one of his servants named Fara Diallo to go and find this scholar, i.e., the alfa Sâlih Diawara, and to ask him to address an invocation to God in the sacred name of the Prophet (God shower his blessings on him and grant him salvation! ), so that he would provide us with water. But the "alfa" () rebuked the servant, saying that the name
of the Prophet (God shower his blessings on him and grant him salvation!) was too respectable a thing to be used to ask for material things: "Ask us rather," he added, "to address our prayer in the name of the consideration which we ourselves enjoy, we sinners." And immediately rising to his feet, he turned to the side of Mecca and cried out, "O my God, we are overwhelmed by thirst and you know my situation better than we do, since you know what is hidden as well as what is apparent." His words were not finished when we heard the thunder and at the same time the rain began to fall on us. We quenched our thirst, watered our beasts of burden, washed ourselves and our clothes, and we remained two days in this place, where the water had formed a river the width of a hundred spears.

However the prince askia Mohammed had distributed dates to the people of the caravan according to his habit. He gave some to everyone, but forgot the alfa Mohammed Toulé. The latter felt a great deal of sorrow in his heart, but he did not show it to anyone. Some members of the caravan imagined that this exception was premeditated, while the others said that it was only an oversight; as for the people of the tent of the alfa Mohammed Toulé, they began to weep, and some murmured against the askia Mohammed. While these various feelings were agitating the caravan, behold, a white camel was seen coming from the east and carrying a considerable load of dates; it split the crowd as it made its way towards the tent of the alfa Mohammed Toulé, and then, when it reached there, dropped the load of dates at the feet of the alfa and returned in the direction from which it had come. Then the alfa Mohammed Toulé got up, approached the load and had the dates distributed
among all the people of the caravan as the askia Mohammed had done, and then he had a share given to the prince askia. Now it turned out that never had anyone seen dates like these. While we followed the camel with our eyes until it had disappeared from our view, the prince askia Mohammed came and bowed to the alfa, kissing his hands and feet and apologizing for his forgetfulness. This is how the divine favor of this scholar, this saint, was manifested to all that day, when he said to the prince: "You had forgotten me because the servant is prone to forget, but the Master never forgets anyone".
It was at the end of the year 903 (1498 CE) that [the askia Muhammad] returned (from Mecca).

Among other singularities and wonderful events that occurred during his pilgrimage, [we may mention] the following facts. The inhabitants of the two noble and sacred cities2 : They came to meet him; he bought a site in the glorious city of Mecca on which he built an inaison and he constituted it as a habous in favor of the noble temple of the Ka'ba; There he had interviews with illustrious doctors and pious and revered personages; 'the sheriff of Mecca conferred upon him the turban3 and conferred upon him the investiture of sovereignty by placing upon his head a blue turban and giving him the title of Imâm.

In Cairo, he met Sidi Abderrahmân Es-Soyoûti, who announced to him the events that would take place in his country. As the askia asked him about the city of Gâo and the future reserved for this city, it is claimed that he replied, "I fear that seditions will be the cause of its loss." Asked next about the city of Tombouctou, -
Mecca and Medina.
As a badge of sovereignty.
he is reported to have () said, "The greatest danger I fear for its inhabitants is that the city will be ruined and annihilated by famine." Then, speaking of the city of Dienné, he said that it would be destroyed and its inhabitants would perish as a result of a sudden invasion of waters, which would submerge them all. And he told the askia other wonderful things. The scholar, the very learned Sidi Mohammed ben Abdelkerîm1 also came to visit the askia.

This prince, it is said, had learned that an inhabitant of Mecca possessed some hairs from the head of the Envoy of God (God shower his blessings on him and grant him salvation!) and that traders came to this man with heaps of gold, asking him to soak these noble and blessed hairs in water, in order to drink this water afterwards and to use it for their ablutions. He went to the man himself and asked him to show him the hair, and as the man showed it to him, he took one of them, put it in his mouth and swallowed it. Ah! what a clever and profitable maneuver! what a heavenly and abundant favor!

It is said that the askia entered the wired enclosure surrounding the tomb of the Envoy of God (God shower his blessings on him and grant him salvation!) and that the Bara-koï, the mansa Koûra, who had entered with him, seized one of the columns of this noble enclosure and exclaimed: "O askia Mohammed, here is the Envoy of God (God bless him and grant him salvation!); here are Aboubekr and Omar (God be pleased with them!): I place myself under their sacred aegis, and I will ask you for several things: The first is that you bring my daughters into your palace only as legitimate wives. - This is El-Megbîli; see note 2, page 15.
That is understood, replied the askia; and what is the second? - 'It is,' replied the Bara-koï, 'that you stop where I stop you, when you order or forbid something.' - That's a given; and what is the third? - That you never put to death anyone who takes refuge in my house or places himself under my protection. That's an agreed thing. It is absolutely necessary, continued the Bara-koï, that you take a firm commitment on this subject in this holy place and that the Envoy of God (God pours his blessings on him and grants him salvation!) be the witness of it. - "It is understood," said the askia, and the pact was thus concluded.

It is reported that when the askia was surrounded by the inhabitants of Bergo1, who had routed his army, he was followed by his sons, who numbered exactly one hundred. The troops of the king of Bergo had surrounded them and separated them from the rest of the army, so that he found himself alone with his children. Then dismounting, the askia offered a prayer of two rik'a2, and then, turning to the side of Mecca, he cried out, "O my God, I implore thee in remembrance of that day when I stood beside the head of thy Envoy in his mausoleum () and I asked you to help me in all the difficulties that I would experience; I beg you, O my God, to help me and my children and to make us escape safely from the hands of these people." Then, getting back on his horse, he said to his children: "Group yourselves before me, so that
US g. This is presumably the country of Bergo or Borgou, inhabited by the Bariba and located southwest of Dendi, in the north of our present colony of Dahomey. Mention of this expedition, which is also related in the Tarikh es-Soudân (see translation, page 125), will be found later.
A rik'a is a set of formulas and gestures whose repetition, regulated according to the hours of the day, constitutes the canonical prayer of Muslims.
I may help you depart out of here". - 'We will never do that,' they replied, 'for we are many, and if some of us die, there will be others left, while you are one, and if you die, we will have no father to take your place.' Then his children placed him in their midst, and they charged at the enemy, routing them and escaping unharmed, without any of them being hurt.

After having thus crossed the circle of investment and having joined his troops, the askia said to them: "Listen and, so marvellous is this thing which did not happen to any human being before me, know, without that it should however surprise you, that God gave me one hundred children of whom none is capable of cowardice nor of defection and who are all valiant horsemen. For it sometimes happens that men whom God has given birth to live without having a single child or have only one who is a perverse and ungrateful child, whereas God has given me a hundred children endowed with all virtues, for which I am very grateful."

Among the miracles attributed to the askia Muhammad is the following. When he arrived in the capital of Môssi-koï after decimating his army and routing it, he stopped by a tree which was in that place and at the foot of which was the idol of the country people; he made a gesture in the direction of the idol and immediately, thanks to the divine intervention, the tree rose out of the ground and fell to the ground. When asked what words he had spoken to the tree and what he had done to it to cause it to fall, he replied: "By God, I did nothing but pronounce the formula 'there is no
An obscure phrase and difficult to translate. ادخلوا امامي حتى اخرجكم
"By these one hundred children he meant both his own children and those of his brother, the Kurmina-fdri Amar". (Marginal note of mscr. A).
divinity except God, Muhammad is the Envoy of God', without adding a single word". This is the account I heard given by my father El-Mokhtâr Gombélé1 (God have mercy on him!).
The askia made this expedition2 during the year 904 [August 19, 1498-August 7, 1499]. It was in this year that our master the jurisconsult Mahmoûd ben Omar was invested with the functions of câdi.
In the year 905 [August 8, 1499 - July 27, 1500], the askia made an expedition against the Bâgana-fâri4.

In the year 906 [July 28, 1500 - July 16, 1501], he made an expedition against Tildza in the Ayar5, where
(without vowels). The author who speaks here is obviously not Mahmoud Kâti, who was son of El-Hâdj El-Motaouakkel, but his grandson. The Tedzkiret en-Nisian cites a câdi of Tendirma by the name of El Mokhtâr who succeeded in 1710 in these functions to his father Mohammed Gombélé, this last name being written also is without any vowel. If we make this câdi of Tendirma the father of the second of our authors, this would make the latter live in the first half of the 18th century, which would be consistent with what we know on the other hand. But the identification is far from certain, first because the Tedzkiret does not tell us that the câdi El-Mokhtâr bore, like his father, the name or nickname of Gombélé, then because the first name of El-Mokhtâr is excessively common, and finally because Gombélé - if, however, this is how one should transcribe - is a nickname of mandinka origin meaning "the Red" which is given to certain individuals because of the color of their skin and hair without ever becoming a family name (cf. Tedzkiret, translation, page 155).
Against the emperor of the Môssi; the Tarikh es-Soudân does indeed place this expedition in 904, as well as the appointment of Mahmud as câdi, since it says that these events took place "in the fourth year" of the 10th century : these are also the terms used by our author (for the comparison of dates, cf, the Arabic text of the Tarikh es-Sudan, pages and following).
This expression "our teacher" here is a term of respect that does not necessarily mean that the author had Mahmud as a teacher.
That is, the chief or governor of the Bâgana. The Bâgana, a vast province dependent on the empire of the Malli, straddled the Hodh and the Sudanese Sahel, west of the lacustrine region that stretches between Lake Débo and Tombouctou.
We have been unable to identify with certainty these two names, the first of which is not vocalized by our author but is vocalized in part in the Tarikh es-Soudân (). As for the Ayar (), it may have been the Aïr or Agadès region.
the kakaki1 appeared, which had never happened before.
During the year 907 (July 17, 1501-July 6, 1502], he went to Dialana2 and then returned to Gâo.

He then mandated seven of his sons, namely Kurmina-fâri () Usmân, the môri Usmân-Sâkidi, Usmân-Koreï3, Souleïmân-Katenga, the Bengafarma Souleïmân, the kalissifarma4 Souleïmân and Omar-Toûtou, as well as the jurisconsults of the city in whose company he had made the pilgrimage, and enjoined them to bring him Sâlih Diawara and Mohammed Toulé. Then he said to them: "All that extends from the place called Issa-keïna5 to the place called Kâ6 will be your property, O Sâlih Diawara, and you others are witnesses of this donation]". This territory included three tribes which were the property of the prince: that of the long-haired Haddâdanké, that of the Fálan and that including the Bella-Koukou®, the Kourka and the Sareï9, all of whom came from the Zendji.

Then he said: "O Mohammed Toulé, I give you the enjoyment of the country that one can travel on a mount starting from Harkounsa-Kaïgoro and traveling straight ahead

(The Diam-Ouali and Sorobanna are descended from an arbi mother and a father who was a blacksmith of the Mâssina.) Things happened as the prince had indicated, and the sun set on Mohammed Toulé as he arrived in front of the trees of Doûdikatia1; after which he returned to the prince, gave him an account of his journey and called down divine blessings on those present).
No expedition took place in the eighth, ninth and tenth years.
In the year 911 [June 4, 1505-May 23, 1506] the prince marched against the Bergo, but he made no expedition in the twelfth year (of the century).

During the year 913 [May 13, 1507-May 1, 1508] he came to camp at Kabara, where he met with three of the descendants of the sheikh môri Haougâro, who were the môri Es-Sâdiq, the môri Djeîba and the môri Mohammed, who had been arrested by the shî Ali during his reign, as mentioned above. They complained loudly to the askia Mohammed of the cruelties and abuses they had endured during the time of shî Ali; the askia caused to be handed over ten slaves and a hundred cows to them, and they set out to return home. On the way, they met their brothers, from the same father and descendants like themselves of môri Haougâro, who were on their way to the askia Muhammad. These having questioned them about this prince, they praised his conduct, his good administration and his generosity, and told them () what they had received from him in the way of
For Harkounsa-Kaïgoro and Doûdikatia, see note 2 on page 53. The words Zendji, Sorobanna, Diam-Ouali, Arbi have been explained in previous notes.
cows and slaves: "We must," the others distributed, "have our share of this present as partners and we will divide it among ourselves in equal fractions. When the first refused, a very lively discussion broke out among them. Things came to such a point that the first three, accompanied by their brothers, returned to the askia Mohammed, to whom they told what had just happened between them and themselves.

The prince welcomed them smiling, full of joy and satisfaction, and said to the brothers, "When I made this gift, I did not have in view all the descendants of the môri Haougâro, and I was only thinking of the three of you who were then present. What I have given them is the share which God had devolved upon them beforehand: therefore it belongs to them in full ownership, since it is God who has allotted it to them." Then he gave the other brothers ten slaves and a hundred cows and said, "This is yours personally." Then he gave the other brothers ten slaves and a hundred cows and said, "This is yours personally, and you will all be entitled to claim the same compensation from me every year as long as I live." After receiving this gift, they showed their gratitude to the prince and prayed to God that the askia would live long and enjoy his empire in peace.

Then they said to him: "We beg you to give us a safe-conduct in writing, so that we may travel to all the cities without our interests being harmed and without being exposed to the risk that one of your soldiers, using us with malice, may molest us and rob us. May God keep you from the fire of hell!" The prince welcomed their request and ordered his secretary to write down what he was going to dictate to him.

I myself saw this safe-conduct, which was shown to me by my maternal uncle, the câdi Ismâïl, son of the jurisconsult towards
the câdi Mahmoûd Kâti'. Worms had eaten away ... a few lines of the lower part of this document and the paper had holes in places. Here is the text: "This is the rescript of the prince of the believers, the khalifa of the Muslims, the just sultan, of one who executes the orders of God, of the askia El-Hâdj Mohammed ben Aboubakar (God make his power and his glory last and grant his divine favor to his descendants for his descendants!). To whoever finds the present written document in the hands of any of the great-grandsons of the pious and virtuous jurisconsult môri Mohammed Haugâro, namely the môri Es-Sâdiq, the môri Djeïba3, Ishâq, Aniâzoko4, Mohammed, Resmâk5, Ali and Belqâssem, all sons of the jurisconsult môri Mâma son of môri Mâmaka6 () son himself of the jurisconsult môri Haougâro (God have mercy on him and let us benefit from his knowledge and piety, so be it): whoever, among those who believe in God, the Last Day and the mission of his prophet the truthful (God shower his blessings on him and grant him salvation!), will find the present writing will have to honor the above-mentioned and take into account their virtues and merits, as well as the glory of their ancestor. Let every wicked man and perverted man give way to his evil inclinations towards them; whether he belongs to our army or to our militia, whether he to our army or to our militia, whether he is one of our servants on tour, one of our slaves or one of

our messengers, he shall not cause them the least damage, nor treat them with disdain or with contempt. God will take vengeance on all those who cause them the slightest harm or injustice. We recommend that all those who come from us, children and grandchildren, to be kind to them, to honor them, and to treat them well. We exonerate them from all responsibility. We exempt them from all state contributions and taxes, so that no one will be able to demand anything from them, not even hospitality. If any suspicion arises about any of them or if someone claims a right against them, no one else will decide the question but me alone or those of my children who will succeed me in my functions. If any of my descendants oppress them or extort from them the least of things unjustly and without right, may God withhold his blessing from him during his reign, may he disturb his empire and bring him to an unhappy end, in consideration of what I have promised in the presence of the Messenger of God (God shower his blessings on him and grant him!), while I was inside while I was inside the fenced enclosure of his mausoleum. (God shower his blessings on him and grant him salvation!). I authorize them and their descendants to marry any woman they want in the whole extent of my kingdom, from the Kanta to the Sibiridougou, which forms the limit between our States and those of the emperor of Malli: the children of these marriages shall be free and their mothers, as a result, will become free also. Exception is
The askia indicates by this that he considered his royal power to extend from the region of the lower Niger valley that lies east of the Dendi (Kanta) to the countries between the Niger and the Bani at the level of Niamina and Segou (Sibiridougou or Tiébrédougou), the country where the domain of the empire of the Malli began.

This last line is followed by four others completely deteriorated so that it is impossible to decipher the text and even to combine the remaining fragments to form words. It then reads: "Attending the drafting of this document was the jurisconsult Aboubakar son of the alfa Ali-Kâra son of the khatib Omar1, the alfaka2 Abdallah ben Mohammed El-Aghlâli: and El-Aqib ben Mohammed Ech-Shérif. The one who wrote it testifies to its validity; his name is Ali ben Abdallah ben Abdeldjebbâr El-Yéméni: may God seal his destiny by granting him the most beautiful of rewards!

The askia then ordered a herald to summon all those of his sons who were present in this place, namely: the kalissi-farma Souleïmân-Kindankaria, the ouaneïfarma4 Moûssa-Yombol, the saio-farma5 Alou6, the

Then the askia added: "May he who has heard of this rescript or has seen it and has not complied () with its provisions be deprived of the divine protection, and with him all his posterity! Then taking the writing in his hands, he folded it and handed it himself into the hands of the eldest descendant of the sheikh môri Haugâro, who was the môri Es-Sâdiq.

The câdi Ismaïl Kâti said, "Of all the decisions made by the askia Mohammed, there is none, to our knowledge, except this one, which continued to be carried out after the arrival of the army of Juder4; all the others indeed were annulled by the children and descendants of the askia Mohammed. It is God who disposes of us, may his will be done!

I will point out that this single decision that the câdi Ismâïl said to have subsisted was itself abrogated after the death of the askia Mohammed-Bounkan son of the balamá Sâdiq5 and that no trace of it remains; I saw with my own eyes selling in the market of Tombouctou a great number of persons descended from the môri Haougâro or from the families derived from him: they were sold although they protested highly that they were descended from the môri Haougâro.
div.note: In Songai "minister of waters," one who was in charge of the police of the river and lakes, of fisheries, etc.
For an explanation of the term kanfâri, see note 1, page 73. There is probably an error in the text here, the holder of the dignity of kanfâri being then Amar-Komdiago.
Ali-Kossoli means in Songai "Ali the young". The reading of the last word is not certain, the mscr, giving it several different vocalizations (Kossili, Kossali and Kossoli).
Moroccan general who seized Gâo and Tombouctou in 1591.
This askia ruled twice, under Moroccan rule, from 1621 â 1635 and from 1635 to 1642, the date of his death.
div.p: Thus the ruin of the power of the askia was due in part to the Songai people; it took place at the beginning of the year 1075 [July 25, 1664-July 13, 1665]1, at which time they showed their hatred and hostility to them. And I suppose it was the curse of the askia Muhammad2 which was then fulfilled in whole or in part and made his descendants fall into baseness and debasement. Let us rely only on God: He is the best of protectors.
In the year 914 [May 2, 1508 - April 20, 1509] Askia Mohammed went to Galamboût and returned at the beginning of the year 915 [April 21, 1509 - April 9, 1510].

It was during this last year that our master Mahmoûd ben Omar made the pilgrimage to Mecca. The duties of câdi4 were devolved, after his departure, upon câdi Abderrahmân; when Mahmoûd was back in Timbuktu, he remained for two years during which the câdi Abderrahmân continued to exercise the functions of câdi without handing them over to câdi Mahmoûd, of whom he was only the interim. The latter made no observations, created no difficulty for him in this
This date provides us with a new indication of the period in which the second of our authors lived and that of the completion of the work (probably the end of the xynº centurymeat). It will be noted that this is the date of the fall of the Saadian dynasty in Morocco and its replacement by the Filalian dynasty; it is also about the date when the Bambara emperors of Segou began to extend their sovereignty over Tombouctou, while the Oulmidden Tuareg began to exercise dominion over Gâo. The last askia who enjoyed any prestige reigned from 1657 to 1668-69: he was Dâoud, son of Hâroun, who was himself a great-grandson of askia Mohammed.
This is the curse pronounced against those who would not comply with the prescriptions of the askia regarding the descendants of the môri Haugâro.
Or "Kilanaboûti (); the vocalization of this word is not absolutely certain in the mscr. The Tarikh es-Sudan gives the same name without any vowel and adds "it is the Malli". We can assume that it is the Galambô or Galam (region of Bakel), which then formed a dependency of the Malli.
From câdi deputy, according to a marginal note from mscr, A.
subject and did not ask him to hand over his credentials. But, following a trial judged at the hearing of câdi Abderrahmân, the jurisconsult câdi Mahmoûd, having learned of the decision rendered in the circumstance by Abderrahmân (), sent him someone to advise him to reform his judgment, which was contrary to the texts of the Qur'an, Sunnah, and Idjmâ'. Abderrahmân refused to do so and wanted to maintain the execution of his sentence. The sheikh made no comment, but the askia Mohammed, having been informed of the matter, dispatched envoys to revoke Abderrahmân and have him hand over the judicial functions to the câdi Mahmoûd.

Arriving at Tombouctou, the prince's messenger assembled the ulama and jurisconsults of that city in the mosque of Sidi Yahya and the câdi Abderrahmân, summoned by order of the askia, went to the meeting. The royal envoy then said to him, "The askia orders you to hand over your duties immediately to câdi Mahmoûd, for you are only his deputy, and, when the deputized official is present, the deputization ceases and is cancelled. Moreover, as long as Mahmud is alive among us, you cannot occupy the post of câdi." Then he strongly reproached him for the lack of tact he had shown in not immediately resigning his powers upon the return of the câdi Mahmoûd. Then, after removing him, the prince's envoys went to the câdi Mahmoûd and enjoined him, in the name of the askia, to resume his title and exercise the functions of it. But the latter energetically refused to do so, despite the insistence to which he was subjected.

As soon as the askia was aware of his categorical refusal, he sent him the notables of his entourage to force him to accept. Mahmoûd consented to it only defeated by
Sunnah is the body of Islamic traditions and Idjmâ' is the unanimous agreement of jurisconsults on a legislative provision.
the arguments which they put to him and only then did he resume his duties (God have mercy on him!).
In the year 917 [31 March 1511-18 March 1512], the askia sent Ali, nicknamed Ali Foulan, and the balamâ Mohammed-Koreï to the Bagana-fâri Mâ-Kati1.

It was in the year 918 [March 19, 1512 - March 8, 1513] that the impostor was killed, i.e. Téniedda, who claimed to be a prophet and envoy of God (the divine curse be upon him!). It was the kanfâri Amar-Komdiâgo who killed him, without the askia having given him the order and without this prince having known about it; starting from Tendirma, Amar marched against Téniedda and God granted him the victory: given that his adversary had more numerous, stronger and more determined troops than his own, the kanfâri Amar could only manage to defeat him thanks to the divine protection.

This Téniedda was chief of the Foûta called Foûta-Kingui3; he was a powerful, valiant, brave prince, gifted with energy and inclined to revolt. Having left the kingdom of Foûta, he had come to Kingui (), settled there and had himself proclaimed king. As to the motive which provoked the expedition of the kanfâri

More commonly known as Tenguella (see about this character in Note 2, page 72).
There are several countries in the Sudan by the name of Fogla, all of which received this name from conquerors who came from the Senegalese Foûta-Tôro or Foûta : thus we have the Foûta-Diallon, the Foûta-Boundou, the Foûta-Kingui, etc. , expressions meaning in the Fulani language "Foûta of Diallon, Foûta of Boundou, Foûta of Kingui, etc. ". The Kingui is the province of the Sudanese Sahel where our present post of Nioro is located and which formerly had as its chief town the city of Diâra.
Or "having separated from the king of Foûta". This refers to the Foûta proper or Senegalese Foûta, which had just been conquered by Koli, the adopted son of Tenguella or Téniedda; the latter, according to Senegalese traditions, had separated from Koli, when the latter had reached Senegal, in order to carry himself into the kingdom of Diâra.
Amar, this is it: there had arisen between the Kaniriga-faren1 and Téniedda, king of the Foûta, quarrels, frictions and rivalries of such a nature that the latter had sworn to ruin the capital of his adversary and to make a desert of it; and, as Téniedda had superior forces in men and horses, the Raniaga-faren appealed to the help of the kanfâri Amar, and for this reason the latter made his expedition.

This is at least the first version we heard of this affair. But later, a person well informed about these events told me that the reason kanfâri Amar had made an expedition against Téniedda was that a Zaghrâni living in Songaï went every year to the Foûta to trade there and that Téniedda, having heard of this man, seized his person, violently and unjustly stripped him of his goods and wanted to put him to death. The Zaghrâni, having succeeded in escaping, fled to the Kourmina-fâri Amar and tried to harm Téniedda in his mind by slandering him and insinuating that he spoke with contempt of the kanfâri. These words made an impression on the latter, who became violently angry and began his expedition against Téniedda).

The Songai people were already well versed in the art of war and the science of combat; they were very brave, very bold and very expert in the tricks of war. Observe, for example, how, at the head of a numerous army, the Kurmina-fâri succeeded in crossing those immense waterless deserts which extend over the distance of more than two months' march, separating Tendirma from the Foûta, and how he was afterwards able to win the victory, seize the
Sovereign soninké of Diâra (see note 6, page 71). This entire passage has already been given by the author, in almost identical terms, during the chapter on the kingdom of Kaniâga.
country, put his opponent to death, and collected enormous booty, all during the year 918. Amar cut off Teniedda's head and brought it back to Tendirma, where it was buried.
In the year 919 (March 9, 1513 - February 25, 1514), the askia made an expedition against Katséna1.

In the year 925 [January 3, 1519-December 22, 1519], he sailed to Kabara during the month of Ramadan and returned to Gâo in the same month. It was on the day of his disembarkation at Gâo that he learned of the illness of his brother, the Kourmina-fâri () Amar-Komdiâgo. He then retraced his steps and went incognito to Tendirma, where he arrived at night, and that same night Amar died and was buried in his palace. The askia stayed there for three days. It is said that on one of those days he rode his horse along the small branch of the river to the place where it ends at Lake Fati3 and that on his way back he exclaimed: "How beautiful and magnificent this country is! Unfortunately, one never finds two people who agree on the same point." When asked the reason for this, he said: "It is because the river that waters it has a tortuous course; consequently, those who drink its water do not have a firm word and its residents do not agree among themselves." He then returned to Gâo. His journey there and back had lasted twelve days, without any of the inhabitants of Gâo having known of his absence until they saw him return.

He gave the duties of Kourmina-fâri to his brother Yahya, whose name is pronounced Yaya. Several versions are in circulation

The text bears "in the fifth (year)"; this is obviously the fifth year after 920; the word "vingt" has been omitted by the author or copyist Moreover, the Tarikh es-Sudan mentions the passage of the askia to Kabara as having taken place on the 15th of the month of Ramadan in the twenty-fifth year of the 10th century.
Tendirma is located at the confluence of the Niger and a channel that connects this river with Lake Fali.
about the latter: some claim that he was the son of a woman of the askia and therefore his son-in-law, others assure that he was his uterine brother, others finally say that he was the son of the brother of Kassaï, daughter of the Koura-koï1 Boukar and mother of the askia. The above-mentioned Kanfâri Yâya remained in power for nine years.

At the end of this period2, the Kourmina-fâri Yâya left his residence to go to Gâo, learning that the askia Moûssacher was taking advantage of the fact that the sight of his father was weakening to depose him. Thus leaving Tendirma with the aim of preventing this maneuver, if necessary by force, Yaya arrived at Gâo and addressed observations to Moûssa and his followers, but they would not listen and persisted in their seditious plans. One day when Yâya had gone out to ride on horseback in the vicinity of the city of Gâo, the askia Moûssa also mounted a horse in the company of his brothers who were friends of disorder, unrest and revolt, and, having followed Yâya on the trail, they joined him at a place called Râs-Arizour (Arizour meaning "the flowing of the water4"). A battle ensued at this place; they defeated Yâya and killed him).

It was at the end of the same year, i.e. of the year 935 [15 September 1528-4 September 1529), that the askia
The text gives the spelling Kara-koï here, as well as a little later, when it had previously vocalized the word Koura koï (see note 3, page 114). In the event that it is the Kara-koï lesson that should be adopted, Kara should probably be taken to mean the city or province of Kara or Kala, located east of the Niger at the level of Dienné.
That is, around 1528.
The eldest son of the askia Mohammed; he was not yet an askia at that time, but became one soon after, as we shall see.
Ari-zour or Hari dyour () indeed means in Songai "flow of water" or "leakage of water" and râs in Arabic means "head"; it is a place located upstream of the city and so called because that is where the current comes from.
Moûssa dethroned his father the askia Muhammad and seized power. But God did not bless his reign. This happened on the day of the feast of sacrifices in the thirty-fifth year of the century (August 15, 1529].
The askia Muhammad had remained in power for 39 years, or, according to some, for 43 years, which is contrary to the truth! He lived 97 years and died during the reign of the askia Ismâïl.

He left many sons: (va) first the askia Moûssa, then the ouaneï-farma Moûssa-Yombol and the koreï-farma 3 Môri-Moûssa, the one who went with the Kourmina-fâri Ousmân4; then he had had three sons by the name of Ousmân, of whom the first was the Kourmina-fâri Ousmân, the other two being Môri-Ousmân-Sâkidi and Ousmân-Koreï5; three of his sons were called Souleïmân: Souleïman-Katenga, the Bengafarma Souleïmân and the kalissi-farma Souleïmân-Kondikoria6; he had three Omar: Omar-Kaï, Omar-Toûtou and Omar-Yoûya; he had three Boukar: Boukar-Kôro, Boukar-Sîn-Fili and Boukar-Kirinkirin; he had three Alis: Ali-Ouâyé, Ali-Kossoli and the Bengafarma Ali-Gandânkiya7; he had three Mohammeds:
In reality, if we refer to the dates given for the advent (898) and the deposition (935) of Muhammad, the reign of this prince lasted from 37 to 38 lunar years.
This word is written sometimes Yonbol, sometimes Yonîl or Bonbol.
"Minister of Whites": the title given to the official in charge of the administration of white families living in the kingdom and Arab or Berber travelers .
The text is obscure; the author is probably alluding to the fact that several brothers of the askia Moûssa, including Môri-Moûssa, took refuge in Tendirma with the Kurmina-fâri Usmân-who had succeeded Yaya-in order to escape the persecutions of the new king (cf. Tarikh es-Soudân, trans., page 134).
Or "Usmân-Kireï."
This character is referred to above as Suleimân-Kindankaria.
Doubtful reading; the same character is called by the Tarikh es-Sudan Ali-Bindi-Keïna or Ali-Yendi-Kaniya (cf. in the work in question the list of the children of the askia Muhammad and his brother Amar, Arabic text, pp. I tretire, translation pp. 211 and 212).
Môri-Mohammed1, Mohammed-Guimbi2 and Mohammed-Kodira, the latter two also known as Mohammed-Dandoumia and Mohammed Et-Tâhir; he also had the hari-farma Abdallah, the askia Ishâq, the askia Ismâïl, Mahmoûd-Doumia, Mahmoûd-Danmaa, Mahmoûd-Boukar, the askia Dâoûd, Ya'qoûb, the Bengafarma Mohammed better known under the name of Habiballah, Khalid, Yâs, Ibrâhim (who was the brother of father and mother of Souleïmân-Kangâga)4, the bâbéli-farma5 Fâma, and many others that it would be impossible to enumerate. Such is the list of the sons of the askia Mohammed whose names come back to my memory at the moment, I have quoted only the smallest part of them.

Among his daughters were Oueạza-Bâni, Oueạza-Oumm-Hâni, Oueạza ()-Aïcha-Kara6, Oueïza-Hafsa7, Aïcha-Bounkan (mother of Mohammed-Kôba), Aïcha-Kara (mother of balamá Mohammed-Ouâo), Bentsi, Hâoua-Adam, Amkoura, Maka- Mâssina, Fourâssa-Mâninko, Kiboro, Safia-Kara, Hâoua- Dâkoï (mother of Hombori-koï ® Monso), Dadala, Nâna-Hassan,
Marginal note of mscr. A: died in the town of Kabi, leaving children whose descendants still live there." There are, in Songai or in the countries that formed the kingdom of Songai, several localities of the name Kabi, Kabbi or Kebbi, notably south of Lake Korienza on the one hand and on the other southwest of Sokoto, between the Dendi and the Gando.
Or Kimbi or Guinabi or Kanabi.
The text bears "the Bengafarma and Mohammed" or "the Bengafarma Ouamohammed".
The latter character is not listed, unless it is the same as Suleiman-Katenga.
This title seems to mean in Songai "chief of crops, minister of agriculture."
Oueạza or oueïdia (from oueï "woman") is a term of respect equivalent in Songai to "madam" and which is placed before the name or suraom of women of quality: Madame-la-Bonne, Madame Oumm-Hâni, Madame Aïcha au teint clair, etc.
The text has "Queiza and Hafsa" instead of "and Oueïza-Hafsa" (cf. Tarikh es Sudan, trans. page 211 and text page ire).
That is, chief of Hombori.
Fati-Diondi (mother of Abderrahmân), Fati-Ouanîna and Kara-Toûdiel (mother of Sidi-Kara).

As for Kourmina-fâri Amar1, he also had many sons, but most of them made neither a name nor a situation that made them famous, although all were brave and valiant warriors. None of his children reigned, with the exception of Mohammed-Bounkan-Kiria2, and none of them held high office, with the exception of Kourmina-fâri Toumané3-Tanfaria. Their existence moreover was short. Among his sons, we can still quote: the tara-farma4 Alfakki, who was the firmest and most human of them, the Bengafarma Ali-Diouleïli, Djafar, Mohammed-Kôro, the Bágana-fâri Abderrahmân, Alou-Sama, Simaïl-Kinkiri, Kiria, Mohammed-Nâni-Koûna and many others, for they were legion. His daughters were: Kibara, who was married first to kanfâri Ya'qoûb and then to the askia Dâoûd after the death of Ya'qoûb; Keïbanou, who was married to a Bara-koï, () the mansa Mâ-Boukel, whose son was the Barakoï Omar; then Nâna-Asma; then Mâ-Mousso, who left a numerous posterity; then Tsata-Diâra and Bentsi-Kara.

All the askia were sons of concubines, with the exception only of the askia Mohammed, while the reverse is true of the kings of the Bara, all of whom were born of legitimate women, except only the Bara-koï mansa Kinta, who was the son of a slave.

The mother of the askia Mohammed, the only one born of a legitimate wife, was called Kassaï and was the daughter of the Koura-koï
The mscr. A bears here, contrary to the lesson found almost everywhere else, "the Karman-fára (or Gourman-fára) Omar."
Or Mohammed-Bengan-Kireï.
Toumané is in Sudan the equivalent of the Arabic name Ousman.
Title which seems to mean in Songai "master of the cavalry".
Boukar. The mother of the askia Moûssa was called Diâra-Korbo. The mother of the askia Mâr-Bounkan1 was Mina-Kirao. The mother of askia Ismâïl was a ouangara woman named Mariam Dâbo. The mother of the askia Ishâq, called Kaltoùm-Berda2, belonged to the tribe of Dâma3. Dâoûd's mother was Sâna-Fârio; the askia El-Hâdj 4 had Mina-Kâya; the askia Mohammed-Bâni had Amassa-Kâro as his mother; the mother of Ishâq5 was called Fâtouma-Bosso and was a Zaghrâni. All of these, it is assured, were concubines.

As for the kings of the Bara, the first of them to occupy power was Kansiri-Maa, who resided in Kinkira6. The first of them who resided in Dyibara was the grandson of the latter: he was Mansa Koura, son of Mansa Moûssa, and his mother was Mariam Sounboun. His successors were: the mansa Souleïmân, whose mother was Yâzi Siré; the mansa Kinta, whose mother was Farama Toûré; the mansa Mâ-Boukel, whose mother was Kourdia Kinta; the
This prince is the same as Mohammed-Bounkan-Kiria; perhaps Mär is put here for Mumari, one of the Sudanese equivalents of Mohammed. As for the word "Bounkan", which generally does not carry vowels, it is here vocalized .بنکن
That is, "Kaltoûm-la-Touareg".
The name of a tribe serve of Tuareg found inside the Niger-Buckle.
Sons of the askia Dâoûd.
This is Ishâq II, the one who was dislodged by the pasha Djouder in 1591.
Or "in Kinkira". This name is probably that of a canton or locality in the interior of the Bara (کنکر).
Djibar () in the text: this is probably the southern canton of the Bara, neighboring Lake Débo, a canton that bears the name Dyibara or Guimbala (country of the great water) in Bambara.
Mansa is a title belonging to the Mandingo language, in which it means "king"; it was borne by all chiefs of the Bara. Mansa Koûra is the one who accompanied to Mecca the askia Mobammed; his name is spelled Kôro in this passage, but elsewhere it is written Koûra.
mansa Boukar-Koûki, whose mother was Fati Bâda; the mansa Dobor, whose mother was Mariam Koumba; the mansa Boukar-Oueïno, whose mother was Aïcha Barada; () the mansa Omar, whose mother was Keïbanou; then the mansa Alou1, whose mother was Namoï and at whose time the arrival of Djouder is placed.2

During the lifetime of the askia Mohammed were born: Mohammed ben Mohammed ben Said, grandson of the jurisconsult Mahmoûd ben Omar ben Mohammed Aqit 3; the jurisconsult Sidi Mohammed4, son of the câdi Mahmoûd Baghayogho (God have mercy on him! ); the jurisconsult Aboubakar ben Mahmoûd ben Omar ben Mohammed Aqît; Ahmed ben El-Hâdj Abmed ben Omar ben Mohammed Aqit, the father of Sidi Ahmed-Bâba5; the jurisconsult and câdi Mahmoûd ben El-Hâdj El-Motaouakkel Kâti6.

As for the alfa Mohammed Toulé, he was the ancestor of the people of Doukoureï7 and the best of their jurisconsults; their family is linked by its genealogy to the Beni-Medâs. This character had accompanied, during his pilgrimage to Mecca, the askia Mohammed, who had the greatest regard and veneration for him. Unfortunately he died without any of his descendants inheriting any part of his science.

This Mahmud ben Omar was the câdi of Timbuktu who has been mentioned several times; he is spoken of in the Tarikh es.Sudan and in Ahmed-Bâba.

This character, the first author of the Tarikh el-fettâch, was indeed born around 1468, the askia Muhammad was already 25 years old but not yet ruling, as seen above.

div.p: It was during the reign of the askia Mohammed that the alfa Sâlih Diawara1, ancestor of the inhabitants of Taoutala, died, who, too, left no child whose name is worth preserving in in writing.

It is said that it was the askia Mohammed who gave the jurisconsult Mahmoûd ben Omar (God be pleased with him!) the woman from whom the câdi Mohammed was born, enjoining him to make her his concubine, which he did indeed. Then the askia Mohammed sent a thousand mithqâls to the jurisconsult Mahmoûd, saying to him: 'If this woman conceives a male child from you, give it the name that I bear and hand over the thousand mithqâls to her; if she has a daughter, give her only five hundred mithqâls and keep the other five hundred for yourself.
div.note: This character is mentioned variously in the Tarikh es-Soudân (cf., translation, pp. 119, 120, 121, and 130); Diawara is the name of a clan that rallies to the Soninke, just as Baghayogho is the name of a Mandingo clan.
Location cited by the Tarikh es-Soudân as being on the road to Dienne to Sansanding (see translation, pages 119, 417 and 419).
